summary: 1 dupondius and 6 asses (Vespasian to Trajan) discovered beneath the concrete bedding for the flagstones at the south-eastern end of the basilica.
126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Stadt Museum Villach, Austria. (73 coins)

summary: 235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).

A hoard of at least 24 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and possibly a silver fibula were allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s nearby village Semaki in Vinnytsia region. The coins were found in an area of 15x15 m. The silver brooch was found on the same area. Based on a photo of five coins, three of which were denarii from the time of Titus, Antoninus Pius and Commodus, one cast copy of a denarius with a portrait of Hadrian and an anonymous quadrans with a portrait of Mars on the obverse and cuirass on the reverse. While the denarii have general preservation and similar bronze oxides, the cast copy of the denarius and the anonymous quadrans are probably not part of the hoard. The further fate of the coins is unknown to me.

Around 200 denarii. The person who ppresented 46 denarii mentioned that in total may have found around 200 pieces. Only 28 coins could be described. One denarius of Antoninus Pius was found in 2010: Vitellius - Clodius Albinus (AD 194-197).
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
Hoard of circa 700 denarii. Only 350 pieces are known: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
Hoard of around 1,000 silver coins: 999 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-211).
disposition: Poltava Local History Museum (954 specimens; inv.nos. 4919-4920, 5090)

summary: The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of about 400 Roman silver coins, found at Torfoot, 7 miles south-west of Strathaven, in a glass bottle, while cleaning a drain. Coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, wife of Antoninus, Crispina, wife of Commodus, and various other Emperors and Empresses, &c., all in good preservation, are mentioned. About fifty of the coins were so much verdigreated and adhering together, that they were broken with a hammer by a rude and unskillful hand, in order to separate them. J. Lindsay, View of the Coinage of Scotland (1845), 265, added Hadrian, Marcus, Caesar, Pompey and Crassus to the list of emperors etc. represented. The three last names may have been due to a misunderstanding of the legends on some coins. True Republican den. would be unusual in a hoard as late as the reign of Commodus.
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.

A hoard of ca. 1100 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the town of Turbiv in the Vinnytsia region. The coins had a strong degree of wear. This information cannot be verified, as neither the coins themselves nor their photographs are available. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).

Towards the end of October 1878 three aurei were discovered in Bliesen between the Church of St. Remigius and the Rhine road. These date from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius. The coins are now in the collection of the Munzkabinett im Rheinischen Landesmuseum. A fourth aureus in the possession of this museum has been associated with the Bliesen hoard. It dates to the reign of Vespasian (72/3) and was acquired from the Bliesen area.
5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
2 denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 denarii were documented: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-19922).
About 5000 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
(200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 66 sestertii from Domitian to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 195 to 196. It was found with a small statue of Mercury.
270 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 183-184).
Two denarii found on a field: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 185).
Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
Unknown initial number of denarii. Sixty-three coins were seen in the collection of the Friends of sciences Society Collection in Poznań: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Friends of sciences Society Collection, Poznań, Poland (63 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Unknown quantity of silver and bronze coins found in a copper vessel. 11 coins in the History Museum in Lom: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. Fournier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
14 coins ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (1 denarius of Trajan; 11 provincial coins: Dium, Koinon of Macedonia, Stobi; 2 uncertain), found in grave 5 in Sevasti.
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
Three denarii found on a field: Trajan 1, Lucilla 1, Faustina II/Lucilla 1

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.
Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Large hoard of Roman denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.
A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
Unknown number of antoniniani, among, those of Aurelian and Severina.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M III 6197-6234 (38 coins)

summary: Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Around 100 denarii, among them, one of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

Unknown originally number of coins. 10 denarii entered the collection of the Center for the Social Sciences in Craiova: Vitellius 1, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) 2, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) 1.
disposition: Center for the Social Sciences, Craiova, Romania

summary: 2 denarii: Titus, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II); silver weight: 4.80 g. Together were found: loop of gold bracteate, 2 gold bands, 3 bronze pins, bronze sword (in miniature), 1 small bronze ring, various bronze fragments.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 304 coins were recovered together with the vessel's sherds: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
A large hoard of 2,218 coins: Vespasian - Commodus. No further information.
The hoard comprised a small iron safe containing two aureii and a variety of jewellery.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France

summary: The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
480 denarii: Republic – Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 155-156).

A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with three silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The content of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: 200 aurei, only 6 were available for study: Galba, Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus.

Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, Sixpenny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).
At least 9 denarii and 1 aureus: Trajan-Hadrian (AD 117-138).
6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
53 large Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii?): Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
2 denarii found on manor field: C. Porcius Cato, Hadrian (119-122).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic

summary: 72 aurei ranging from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (with Diva Faustina I and M. Aurelius Caesar) found in the vicus of Lousonna within a house. The coins had been divided in two concealments of each 35 coins, hidden in the floor. Two further coins were found nearby.
15 denarii: Vespasian/Titus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 113-114 with four intruding coins.
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.
Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: 5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).

The hoard was found at a natural spring and comprised votives (including numerous wooden statuettes) as well as '149 copper coins of Roman emprors'. 79 of these coins were identified. The others were illegible.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.

Discovered in 2007 in a field, near a village, between the village and the Lyasnaya river; the coins were scattered over an area of 500x100 m and had two large concentrations (two hoards?). Included at least 500 denarii, of which only 20 are available for study (Vespasian-Clodius Albinus). Information about the hoard in 2009 came to the archaeologist V. Belyavets, and in the spring of 2010 V. Sidarovich examined the place of the find. In the same field, other items were found: fragments of silver brooches, a gold brooch, a spearhead, a gold ring (?). Their relation with the hoard is doubtful (items from the settlement?)
10 coins found together in a tomb (purse?): Domitian -Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 52 denarii were found with a hand-made ceramic vessel: Mark Antony – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A small hoard of 21 Roman imperial denarii (from Domitian to Commodus) and three bronze artefacts was found by a treasure hunter in March 2016 somewhere in Central Ukraine, probably in Cherkassy region. On March 10, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity was published information about the hoard and a photo of the coins and items from it (the finder identified the deposit as a “purse of denarii”). There is no information about the conditions of the find. The coins have heavy wear, one of the coins has strong oxide traces. The bronze items are rectangular in shape and are most likely belt plate: two measure 4.5x0.7cm and one (with six rivets) measures 4.3x1.3cm. In March 2016 the hoard was sold at the Violity auction, and the further fate of the coins is unknown.

A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for one Lycian drachm of Trajan.
5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: 800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Hoard of 11 sestertii found adjacent to the large Cadeby hoard.

A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.
The hoard comprised 831 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).
(?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
20 coins: 18 denarii, 2 bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138).

A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and one Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), one Lycian drachm of Trajan and one contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: A hoard of 8 complete and 1 halved Roman provincial copper alloy coins (Antioch, Beroea, Laodicea, uncertain) from the reigns of Trajan and Antoninus Pius, found at Assur, iC6V, West, 50 cm below the surface of the hill.

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

A deliberate deposit from the excavations at Ashwell. E Ghey writes: Group 2002 T215 (5) consisted of items in a 'placed deposit' in context 203. This deposit consisted of two copper alloy units of Tasciovanus, four copper alloy units of Cunobelin, one silver Icenian unit, a pierced dupondius of Claudius, an as of Vespasian and an as of Hadrian. The non-coin objects consisted of second century AD Roman objects (a brooch, mounts, numerous fragments of iron mail armour and implements, a fragment of a pipe-clay figurine) and part of a Bronze Age spearhead, in addition to fragments of pottery, animal bone and cremated bone. The as of Hadrian places deposit (5) in the second century AD at the earliest; a time in which the coin evidence as a whole suggests a reduction in activity at the site.
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Split, Croatia; partly dispersed

summary: A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
Originally, 222 coins. 133 denarii are documented: Nero - Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Iron Gates Museum, Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania (122 coins); inv.no. 562-683; private collection, Bucharest, Romania. (11 coins)

summary: 29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: 97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.

The hoard comprised a total of 1,133 coins, including 1,031 sestertii, 68 dupondii, 26 asses, 3 dupondii or asses and 5 imitations: Gaius - Commodus (AD 188-189). They were found during the excavation of building C in a Gallo-Roman vicus.
31 denarii found in a ceramic vessel inside a mound: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Weight: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: A hoard found in a field south of Castlethorpe, comprising 20 denarii and 35 bronze coins, up to Lucius Verus.
237 provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144). Two sacks found in a house during excavations.
307 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Maramureș, Baia Mare, Romania

summary: 18 denarii of which two imitations (one hybrid) found as a lump: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). The imitation denarii were struck with the same dies as other two denarii found in Ukraine (Dymowski 2017)

A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install phone cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.
disposition: Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, Monnaies et Médailles, Lausanne

summary: The hoard originally comprised 21 bronze coins found with an amphora: Vespasian-Antoninus Pius (73-145 AD). Only 18 coins are still available.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Iatly

summary: 10 coins. Unknown denominations: Augustus - Hadrianus (AD 117-138).

The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
(c. 400) 3 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: Archaeological Museum Charleroi, Belgium 13 coins, only 5 retrieved)

summary: 3760 silver coins, only 10 are available for study: Vitellius - Commodus (AD 180)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania (10 coins in 1914); otherwise, dispersed.

summary: 21 bronze coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) published in am auction catalogue without details on the circumstances of discovery.
Over 200 silver coins from Vespasian to Hadrian (Ad 117-138). No detailed information.
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
Six denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1,750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.

Portions of this hoard were acquired by the ANS in 1911 and 1912, totaling 783 coins. 451 of these could be identified in the museum's collection, including 448 denarii, Vespasian to Commodus (AD 183-184) and 3 Cypriote didrachms of Vespasian. This hoard is said to have been discovered in Larnaka, though no details are available.
60 denarii found, probably, with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
135 denarii found by metal detecting: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). Together were found: Flint pendant; an iron chain; a ceramic spindle.

274 coins: 75 sestertii, 117 dupondii, 74 asses, 7 dupondii/asses, 1 bronze medallion: Gaius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-176). Together with the coins were found: 2 silver pans, 1 silver plate, silver wire bracelet.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.

In 2010 archaeological excavation of the northern part of Tyritake city-site (site XXVIII) a boxlike altar made of limestone tiles was found in Room I. Altar clearing uncovered two golden staters of Bosporus kings Eupator and Sauromates II, which are most likely to have been offerings to Dionysus. Sauromates II’s stater suggests dating offerings to Dionysus to AD 179 or a little later.
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only two pieces are known: Trajan, Hadrian.
150 denarii. 145 coins entered the History Museum in Svishtov: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150); silver weight of c. 275.8-468.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1614-1735 (145 coins)

summary: Unknown number of denarii. V. Haralanov studied 52 pieces: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: A mixed hoard of 18 coins (Vitellius - Diva Faustina II) was unearthed in the southern area of the civilian town. The date of the latest coin is given as AD 145/161 in FMRD, but the reference of that coin (RIC 1383) is dated to AD 163-164.
34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

During excavations on the site of the ancient town of Lyka, a hoard of 7 provincial coins of the Koinon of Macedonia (Hadrian - Faustina II) was found in trench II, in a very burnt layer, near a cencer and in the same depth with it and nearby silver votive plaques with relief representation. These have been interpreted as remnants of a ritual act, a "sealed group" of votive offerings in honour of a deity.
Unknown originally number of coins. 42 denarii: Otho - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 78.0-122.8 g.
41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.

In 1884 a large hoard of Roman bronze coins was found in the area of Mindelzell. 30 specimens arrived in a private collection in Memmingen, of which 12 were later bought by the Memmingen museum. They are now lost.
21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).

Unknown original number of coins. 184 denarii of which two imitations: Vespasian - Didius Julian (AD 193). Found together with a "belt set of one massive silver buckle for a sword belt and two buckles for a girdle. The find also contains eighty-four silver belt plaits. This belt set, dating to the latter half of the 5th century AD (phase D2 of the Great Migration Period), is a girdle for bladed weaponry."
disposition: The State Museum of Military History and Natural Preserve “The Kulikovo Polye”, Tula, Russia (inv.no. BX 1823/1-184)

summary: 45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'

A hoard of 757 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver ingot was discovered by a treasure hunter on January 11, 2018 in the Lviv region. Information about the find, the silver ingot and a general photo of the bunch uncleaned coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on 11 and 12 January 2018. According to the finder, the hoard was discovered in the forest at a depth of 30-40 cm. Initially a few slipped coins were found, and then the rest of the hoard. Among the coins, a silver ingot (ca. 8.7x1.5 cm) and a fragment of pottery were found. Only photos of 17 coins and the silver ingot were published separately. The further fate of the hoard is unknown, however, most probably it was sold at the Violity auction. Coins: Nerva (1), Hadrian (4), Hadrian (Aelius) (1), Hadrian (Antoninus Pius) (1), Antoninus Pius (3), Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (1), Marcus Aurelius (3), Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (1), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (1), Commodus (1), no information (740).

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
Two denarii of Commodus (AD 186); silver weight: 4.66 g.
513 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102)
disposition: Museum of Art History, Vienna, Austria (1847)

summary: 115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).
Unknown originally number of coins. 27 denarii are kept at the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan – Commodus (AD 185).
disposition: Institute of Archaeology ”V. Parvan”, Bucharest, Romania (27 coins).

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: 23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) found in an Iron Age warrior grave.
Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
The hoard comprised 20 denarii from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192) and was found inside an ostrich egg.
17 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 186-187)
disposition: Collection L. Eloy, Namur, Belgium (14 coins), in 1966

summary: The hoard comprised 86 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus, although the author proposes a deposition date in the reign of Postumus.

Lake Borresø surrounds the medieval castle of Lilleborg. During the draining of the lake in 1832 a mixed gold- and silver hoard was found. "Some" gold fingerrings, of which only one was recovered, and "several" denarii, of which sixteen were handed over to the later National Museum, were found "as if packed into something which had now disappeared".
272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: 3 coins, of which one aureus of Trajan (AD 114-117).
771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were two ceramic vessels buried at 2 m one from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 40 denarii entered Museum Collection in Opole in 1973:
disposition: Municipal Museum Opole, Poland (40 coins in 1973)

summary: 408 denari found by metal detecting: Nero - Hadrian. No further detail.

Over 40 Roman bronze coins, nummi of the Constantius II and the Houses of Valentinian I and of Theodosius I. Unearthed in 1888 by villagers digging a grave. No further details were reported. Bell, the then Archaeological Commissioner, was able to secure 40 pieces. The coin types were: Constantius II: fel temp reparation (falling horseman). House of Valentinian I: concordia auggg (Roma or Constantinopolis). House of Theodosius: salus reipublicae (victory/captive); virtus exerciti (emperor/victory); gloria Romanorum (two emperors).
72 denarii: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 180-192).

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).
The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
"1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: 91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 40 denarii found in a ceramic vessel. Majority belongs to Hadrian.
Few dozens of denarii of the Antonine dynasty (AD 96-192). Only 10 denarii are known: Trajan, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius.
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

14 coins (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius, mostly bronzes) were found embedded in fire debris, on terrain M, Handwerkerbau (Fläche 60, Planum 0-1). N.B. Coin 1 (Vespasian) is wrongly described as a denarius in FMRD.

A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the two Faustinae (AD 138-180).
2,250 denarii: Galba – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.

The hoard comprised a double deposit within a single room of a building. In one corner of the room, there were four coins, including one of Marcus Aurelius, 1 of Lucilla and 2 of Commodus. In the opposite corner, there was an identical deposit.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.
Three denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
2 denarii of Hadrian
Unknown number of Roman bronze coins, only 3 pieces are known: Augustus, Nero, Hadrian
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.
Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: "About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre d'entrée, II, p. 230, no. 12.428

summary: The hoard comprised 11 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 117-138.
Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A hoard of 20+ Roman silver coins (i.e. certainly denarii), found while digging out peat on the Dörpstedter Moor.
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.
49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
Unknown quantity of bronze coins. Three sestertii: Claudius I, Nero, Marcus Aurelius were offered to the Regional History Museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria

summary: 103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
A hoard of unknown originally number of coins. 18 denarii were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.
(180) 141 silver coins: 140 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm dating from the Republic to Trajan.
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (141 coins)

summary: 7 denarii: Vespasian 3, Nerva 1, Trajan 1, Marcus aurelius 2 (AD 166-167).
36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.
2500-3000 denarii. 250 pieces were bought by the National Museum in Sofia: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
8 bronze coins - 7 sestertii, 1 as - range: Galba- Trajan (AD 103-111) found in a ditch on the area of the Roman cemetery.
The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 85 sestertii, the majority of which were rendered illegible by oxidation. However, those that could be identified range from issues of Hadrian to Commodus.
Four denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely
102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.
Unknown originally number of coins. 78 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 189).
disposition: Museu da Região Flaviense, Chaves, Portugal

summary: Five denarii, from the reigns of Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, and Commodus, discovered in a garden in Berlin-Lichterfelde in 1919.

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).

The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 13 silver coins dated between AD 62/3 and AD 123.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (1 Antoninus Pius), Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous Commodus), found in grave 4 in Sevasti.
Unknown initial number of coins: 28 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166); silver weight: 54.2-84.4g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.no. M I 233-250

summary: A find of 45 Roman denarii (Otho - Antoninus Pius) was made in a garden in Vicht. The coins were found in charcoal residues.
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
(32) 2 denarii: Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).
Two aurei, Domitian (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) found in sequential years, in the same forest. Close chronological range.
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).

summary: Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 36 coins including 33 sestertii (1 subferratus) and 3 dupondii terminating with issues of AD 191-192. All coins are worn, so this is most probably a 3rd c. deposition.

In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).
55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, one hoard.
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.

6 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Trajan - Commodus (AD 191-192); silver weight: 10.46 g. Found together with Bronze fibula, bronze sheet, bronze bar, iron knife, iron mounting, fragment of glass vessel, glass paste bead, amber bead, potsherds.

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: A hoard of 304 silver coins (303 denarii and 1 drachm), ranging from Nero to Commodus, found in summer 2019 (with 6 additional coins found in 2020) on the Adlerberg, near Pratteln.
Heap of sestertii, 6: Trajan 4, Commodus 1, uncertain 1 (AD 180-192).
Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: 35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard comprised 2 denarii (Trajan, Hadrian) and 25 aes coins ranging from Domitian Caesar to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (20 coins); lost (7 coins)

summary: (c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
75 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
disposition: Museum of Southern Podlasie, Biała Podlaska, Poland

summary: Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: A hoard of denarii found at Brixworth, in 1892. It is complete except for one denarius of Antoninus Pius of uncertain reverse. Coins range from Vespasian to Crispina.
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).
(c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: Funerary deposit of 5 denarii in a Late Roman grave: Trajan - Commodus (AD 192). In the same grave were found: a bronze brooch, an iron brooch, an iron bracket, one thorn, an iron firesteel and two knives.

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.

A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and one Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).
Unknown originally number of coins. 20 denarii are kept in the Town museum of Târgoviște: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149).
The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.
Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only seven of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
The coins were found together, in a burnt layer 25 cm deep under Plattenstraße at Ritona.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
Grave find of 5 denarii (1 plated) Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 134-138)
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
(200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only three coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard
12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
22 denarii, part of a hoard: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: 80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
9 denarii and 2 aes (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found in Room 28.
20 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189). Among them two imitations. Together it was found an iron axe typical for the Chernyakhov culture (4th-5th centuries AD).
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.
8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).
In 1934, 40 denarii and 12 sestertii were found with an urn in a field north of Narcott Lane. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.

A small hoard of six Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian — Hadrian (AD 117-138) was discovered by treasure hunter in 2014, possibly in Rivne region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on November 28, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the find was discovered about two years ago before publication in a ploughed field. The coins were collected from a small area, but he did not probe to sondage on the place of find, assuming that he would find new finds after each ploughing. However, he has not found any new coins at the site in two years. All coins are equally well preserved (minimal worn) and close chronologically, which allows them to be considered as one deposit. In December 2016 and January 2018, the coins were sold on Violity auction. Coins: Vespasian (Titus) (1), Titus (2), Hadrian (3).
257 denarii found with an amphora: Republic – Commodus (AD 191-192).
10 bronze coins found during archaeological excavations: 5 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 3 asses: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: History Museum, Svištov, Bulgaria; inv.nos OF 3583-3588; HCF, inv.no. 886-889

summary: The hoard comprised 9 silver coins and 1 bronze coin dated to the second century AD.

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.
(90) 27 denarii: 7 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel.
Four asses found during the excavations. To be checked whether were found together.
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).
200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
A hoard of 24 denarii, found on the Dwoberg in 1795. Of these, 22 (Hadrian - Commodus) were found to be in the Oldenburg state museum.

9 denarii (Vespasian to Trajan) found among the infill of a trench carrying a conduit to service latrines in Building B, outside the north-western corner of the fort. Wheeler (1927) dated the infill (and therefore the construction of the conduit) by the date of the latest coin, arguing that its fine condition supported a deposition soon after its issue around AD 120. Simpson (1967) agreed that the hoard must have been deposited at about this time, but added that the accompanying pottery indicated the conduit and trench belonged to the later second or third centuries. The hoard, therefore, is likely to have been disturbed and moved from its original place of burial among the soil and other waste material used to fill the trench.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 denarii provided information on the issuers: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184).
disposition: Zasadniczej Szkoły Zawodowej w Krasniku Fabrycznym, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of 14 denarii. For further details and images see WMID-01F18E. Unpublished catalogue by Richard Abdy.
Hoard of 17 denarii (Mark Antony - Augustus) and 29 sestertii (Nerva - Hadrian) (AD 117-138).
The hoard comprised 301 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 300 were of Nero with a single coin of Hadrian. They were acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
Purse(?) of four sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian I 2 (AD 121-122) found near a wall in the area of the civil town.

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
Hoard of around 200 denarii found with a small ceramic vessel. Only 34 coins were documented: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Historical Museum, Moskow, Russia (inv.nos. 98100-1; 036 658-1; 036 685 - 28 coins); Historical Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (inv.no. 12607/1-6 - 6 coins)

summary: (460) 452 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: M. Antony - Marcus aurelius (AD 176-180).
13 denarii found with a money-box: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-154).
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
The hoard comprised 9 aurei found near the 'Caserne' of Autun. The aurei dated from Vespasian to Faustina I, and may be just a small part of a more important hoard.
The hoard comprised 16 coins with the denominations not given. The hoard was found on the Barre farm, while making repairs to the farmyard.

Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: Unknown number of aurei of the Anoninian house (the number expressed were between 5,000 and 9,000). Only one piece of Antoninus Pius was identified.
(c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: c. 367.1-588.9 g.
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.
18 denarii were discovered in the vicinity of the village of Raksha. Fifteen were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 192).
The hoard comprised 24 bronze coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
130 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 360.44 g. Together with the coins were found two bronze rings.
Circa 300 denarii were discovered while plowing. Denarii of Antoninus Pius and Commodus were mentioned.
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only two of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.
The Cheshire HER lists "A small hoard comprising a silver denarius of Faustina II (AD 176), two unidentified Roman bronze coins and a bronze dolphin-type booch datable to 1st to 2nd century AD".

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
Five aurei found in grave no. 6: Nero, Galba, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found 11 drachms of Gotarze and 3 denarii of Augustus.

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of stones and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
The hoard comprised approximately 1,600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: This hoard was found in a Roman building. It consisted of 7 denarii, ranging from the late Republic to Antoninus Pius. The coins lay stratified in a roll and the find appears to be complete.

A hoard of 19 provincial coins, found in grave T7 in the roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. pl. 18-19. They comprised 3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, 15 coins of Amphipolis from the Antonine period and 1 that remains to be identified.
Around 400 denarii found with a clay pot. 338 coins are known: Nero - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (294 coins), Museum Sandomierz (8 coins), Museum Ostrowiec Świętokrzyski (12 coins), Poland

summary: According to Carlier, the hoard filled a hat(!) and is likely to have originally comprised at least 600 pieces.Although originally comprising more than 600 coins, the hoard was quickly dispersed. The forest administration confiscated 98 coins, Carlier bought approximately 300, the brothers Gérin took 40, while Demonteville, the librarian of Douai, took 100 sestertii, 5 or 6 'middle bronze' and 12 silver coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) - Commodus) (AD 181-190).
28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: Hoard of 11 denarii.
A hoard of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), found in a megalithic grave in an urn also containing ashes. The grave was located 20 m away from the mansion of Fickmühlen.
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.
Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".
6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
12 denarii (Hadrian and Antoninus Pius) found among charcoal, animal bone, and other debris inside the furnace next to Turret 1.
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).
Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).

A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
76 gold coins found in the nineties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
272 coins found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 119-122).
The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprises 17 asses from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The hoard originally comprised an undetermined amount of denarii. Only 12 coins are known: Trajan-Marcus Aurelius (114-175 AD).
A hoard of one denarius of Divus Antoninus Pius and one Roman Provincial coin of Marcus Aurelius minted in Edessa, found in grave 22 in the western cemetery in Pella.
12 denarii: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 178). Some doubts have been expressed as the coins are now in a private collection.
Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.
112 bronze coins: 111 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Over 600 bronze coins found with ceramic vessel. Only 11 pieces are recorded: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 163-164).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueología e Etnología, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.
Hoard of 1000 denarii of the Antonines and 6 aurei of Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.
Unknown initial number of coins. 91 denarii in the Regional History Museum in Pleven: Otho - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 975 1-70

summary: Hoard of 31 denarii. Only one denarius of Antoninus Pius is known.

A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in three textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)
6 sestertii recorded with the PAS, 3 further from excavation of the site (see Amber Valley barbarous radiate hoard). Not classed as Treasure.
The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
(50-60) 13 bronze coins: 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-155).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (13 coins), in 1808

summary: A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.

Around 400 denarii found during archaeological excavations. Only 25 denarii provide information on issuers: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together with the coins was also a silver bar of 155g and, possible, a brooch.
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (25 coins)

summary: Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 25 coins were seen: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoards with Strunga I and III.
Hoard of 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Two denarii are documented: Faustina II, Commodus.
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: 735 denarii found with ceramic vessel and a textile bag: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 195). Found together with a silver T-brooch within a Sarmatian settlement.
