disposition: Numismatic Collection of the Institute of Archeology, Iași, inv. no. 323370 (the brooch)

summary: The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
50 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 137.84 g.
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.
2 Iron Age gold quarter-staters, 18 denarii and 1 quinarius to Antoninus Pius and 6 copper-alloy votive objects.
27 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Few hundreds, 150 were documented: Republic - Commodus (AD 186-187).
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.

A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.
Unknown number of initial coins. 20 pieces - unknown metal - are kept in the Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology in Bucharest: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (Ad 138-161).
disposition: Coin Room of the Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2,804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)

summary: 37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
32 bronze coins found glued to each other: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
(c. 3000-3500) 474 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)

A Roman burial was discovered in the spring of 1929 in widening the south side of the Ashford-Maidstone-London road. This almost certainly represents an untouched cremated deposit. Together with other objects, it contained 18 gold coins or disks.

47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.

The hoard comprised 50 Roman coins which were thought to be bronzes. There is no further information on denominational composition. It was found on communal heathland and pasture, at a very shallow depth. The majority of the coins were collected together by M. Auvray, mayor of Aclou.

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest ones date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.
Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).
30 bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m eastward from the hoard Koropie 2008 2
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: 177 denarii with portraits of emperors from Vespasian to Trajan and two denarii of Mark Antony's 'legionary' series. The denarii were found with a ceramic vessel. The metal analyses, fresh minting loo-alike state of preservation for the large majority of the coins as well as the overweight for most of the coins reveal a 'hoard' of ancient counterfeited coins. The dating of coin type is based on the genuine prototype, otherwise, it looks that they were all minted in/after AD 116.
disposition: Museum of National Union, alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 'a vessel containing 100 sestertii': Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.
A hoard of 12 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) was found during the archaeological excavation of a building thought to be a granary and comprised of thirteen Denarii coins.
Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: Hoard of 47 Roman aurei documented in the archives of the Real Academia de la Historia - Antonio Delgado Fund: Nero - Antoninus Pius for Faustina II (AD 145-161).
Three aurei; Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I.
300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla) (AD 193).
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. According to some incriptions the issuers were Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (ANTONINVS PIVS, ANTONINVS ARMENIACVS). Six or eight denarii were noticed.
Hoard of 177 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 197). Together were found two silver rings and one of gold.
2 sestertii of Antoninus Pius
The hoard comprised 144 silver and two gold coins dated between 32-31 BC and AD 124-128, buried in a clay juglet.
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.

"In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including one of Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of 183 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.

The hoard (5 bronze coins ranging from Domitian to Faustina I) was found in 1964 northwest of the Jewish cemetery in house pit 27-29 of Ernst-Kahn-straße, in a depth of 30 cm. The coins lay in a varnished pot. The hoard remain in private possession.
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
Fifty bronze coins were discovered in Roux, but only 9 were preserved, ranging in date from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: 1,055 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (1,042 coins; inv.no. C 706); History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (8 coins); private collections (5 coins)

summary: Over 200 silver coins. 168 are known: 166 denarii, 2 drachms of Lycia: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Originally 5 denarii, 1 preserved: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186). Found together with 1 gold finger ring, 3 silver finger rings.
c. 20 denarii: Vitellius - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
28 sestertii: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Collection E.C. Lefèvre, Brugge, Belgium, in 1851 (28 coins)

summary: 150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.
166 bronze coins: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Asturias, Oviedo, Spain

summary: Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
17 silver and bronze coins in Principia/barrack: 1 denarius, 1 quinarius, 2 sestertii, 7 dupondii, 6 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-138)
Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
4 denarii: Vitellius, Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-160).

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
16 denarii (Galba - Hadrian) coins were found, covered with a terra sigillata plate, on Tiefenthaler Str.
11 denarii found in a purse (vanished): Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: Centrul de Studii de Istorie și Arheologie, Timișoara, Romania; inv.no. 237/2005

summary: A mixed hoard of Syrian tetradrachms, Cypriote tetradrachms / didrachms, and denarii, ranging in date from Nero to Hadrian. One coin of Vespasian is countermarked by Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-180), which is why the closing reign is given here as Marcus Aurelius.
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised 60 silver coins and some bronzes, including one of Faustina I.

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
The hoard comprised 41 denarii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus.

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
A hoard of silver and bronze (perhaps also gold) coins. There is only data for two coins of Antoninius Pius.
Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.
(14) 10 coins of unknown denomination: Celtic, Republic, Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
A hoard of Roman aurei and their imitations was discovered in an earthen pot: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).

A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
The total number of coins is apparently 1067 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 152-153).
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Vespasian 1, Nerva 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I 1, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2429

summary: A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a mixed hoard of gold, silver, and bronze deposited in relation to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
15 sestertii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Three aurei found at the bottom of "an old wall": Faustina I, Faustina II under Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar). The hoard was found by a farmer.

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.

A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 15 coins were documented: Hadrian (Aelius Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178). Kropotkin suspected that it may be the same hoard as Sosnitsa.
disposition: University Museum, Kyiv, Ukraine (15 coins until 1917)

summary: 9 coins: 1 aureus, 3 denarii, 1 sestertius, 4 asses: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138)

The hoard comprised at least 227 silver coins: 119 Nabatean denarii, 14 provincial tetradrachms of Antioch, 5 didrachms reattributed to Antioch (Trajan), 5 tridrachms and 33 drachms of Trjan reattributed to an Arabian mint, and 51 imperial denarii, down to AD 122.
disposition: Israel Antiquities Authority (108), Ecole Biblique, Amman Museum

summary: 62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)
13 denarii found in a mound next to ceramic vessels: Antoninus Pius - Commodus(AD 180).
disposition: Frisian Museum, Leeuwarden (FML A 1129-1141), 2 coins lost.

summary: The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).

This hoard of 43 aurei, ranging from Nero to Marcus Aurelius, was discovered in June 2000 during the archaeological excavation at Plantation Place, Fenchurch Street, in the City of London. The coins were discovered in situ within a uniform context of silty brick-earth with organic inclusions. The absence of coins of Commodus suggests a deposition date probably no later than AD 180.
Unknown number of Roman coins. Five denarii were placed in a liturgical cup in Limanowa!
Unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. Only 41 denarii are recorded: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Diva) (AD 176).
Initially were found 81 coins. 44 coins: 1 cistophorus, 1 sestertius, 9 asses, 33 unknown bronze denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Arheoloski Muzej Istre, Pula, Croatia (44 coins); othewise dispersed

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 145 denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 178-191).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; private colection V. Heisu from Parava (145 coins)

summary: NA
16 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: 171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: 15 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 161-180). Only 7 denarii are kept in the coin room of the National Museum of Slovenia in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia, 7 coins; dispersed

summary: 85 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel within a burial ground of the Wielbark Culture: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 184).
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
Over 60 denarii found on a field during 19th-21st centuries: Vespasian - septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
disposition: National Museum of Archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (6 coins); Private collection (21 coins)

summary: Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
15 AE to AD 195.
317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
Hoard of didrachms and drachms of the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. 8 coins have been purchased by the local museum in Zugdidi: 5 didrachms Trajan, 2 didrachms Hadrian, 1 drachm Trajan.

54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
(c. 600) 300 silver coins: 299 denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).
(c. 50) 25 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 3 asses: House of Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169)
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: 3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
64 bronze coins: sestertii, dupondii and asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
(200) 17 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 11-180).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.

1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).
237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
110 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Dispersed.
Initially 368 denarii, nowadays, 367: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 1009.47 g.
disposition: The National Historical Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 10155/1-167, 169-368); Stockholm Numismatic Institute, Stockholm (inv.no. 179)

summary: 556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.

The first 20 (?) denarii from the hoard were discovered by schoolchildren in 1968, eight of them were transferred to the Coin Room of the Belarusian State University. V. Ryabtsevich tried to establish the place where the hoard was found, but to no avail. In the first hoard's publication the village of Žukievičy was named as its location. After that, at the hoard's place, amateurs conducted further searches for it. Separate denarii were found, two of which (Trajan and Antoninus Pius) were transferred by V. Kakareka to the Coin Room of the Belarusian University. The rest of the hoard was discovered by treasure hunters in 2011 near the village of Aliekšycy: 426 denarii and 18 fragments of brooches, which were donated to the Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus. Later, 10 more coins were transferred there. In total, 446 coins are known from the hoard (Vespasian-Septimius Severus).
disposition: Coin Room of the Belarusian State University (10 coins); Museum of the National Bank of the Republic of Belarus (436 coins)

summary: Four coins of Bar Kochba (AD 132-136).
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
600 denarii. 361 pieces were examined: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138); silver weight: 669.3-1389.9 g.
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.
110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: Hoard of 200 bronze coins: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised a large number of silver denarii of Clodius Albinus (approximately 15 pounds in weight or 2,000 pieces).
70 coins: 35 sestertii, 27 dupondii, 8 asses hidden in the wall of a Roman building: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Antonine period, none later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: Hoard bought by E.T. Newell in Cairo in Dec. 1923, found near Sakha. It comprised 299 coins: 33 Greek silver coins from the 2nd and 1st c. BC, 261 denarii (Nero to Trajan) and 5 provincial silver issues of Trajan (one Arabian drachm; three drachms of Cyrenaica and one hemidrachm of Cyrenaica).
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.
Four aurei (Nero to Antoninus Pius) recorded at 4 different points in time, between 1996 and 2002, clearly forming a hoard. Many other metal-detected finds from site, Roman-post-medieval.

The hoard was found in a well. It contained 57 aurei including issues of Nero, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina). The coins were accompanied by 3 ceramic vessels, fragments of fineware pottery, 4 terracotta models in the form of portrait busts and a further figurine in the form of a miniature goddess in a biga.

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.

A hoard of ca. 500 (?) Roman imperial denarii was discovered by treasure hunters in February 2014 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and a general photo of two part of the coins was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on December 27, 2014. According to the finders, the coins were found in a field, on an area of 5x5 meters, together with a silver buckle (only the frame of the buckle is preserved). The search for the coins lasted for two days. This field, according to the informants, was quite popular among local treasure hunters. Some of the coins from the hoard found on the second day were stuck together. There are two general photos of the coins: one shows at least 60 denarii, the other at least 71 (there are also photos of this part of the hoard on a scale, together with the silver buckle: 336.5 g). These photos were published by different treasure hunters, so they most likely represent different parts of the hoard. I managed to identify only a small part of the coins in the photos: 13 coins in the first photo and 13 coins in the second photo. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.

The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: 9 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
86 denarii: Mark-Antony - Commodus (Crispina) (AD 180-191).
Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.
(8) 5 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151)

4 denarii found in the lid from a wooden box (Cassette) found in a princely grave: Hadrian 1, Marcus Aurelius/Lucius Verus 1, uncertain 2. In the same grave was found on the left side of the Skeleton an aureus of Clausiud II (see single gold find WROCŁAW ZAKRZÓW).
Three denarii (Nerva - Faustina II), found with others on a field in Halsmühlen.

At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 10 pieces are known: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-192).
The hoard comprised 96 bronze coins from the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/6).
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)
The hoard comprised at least 54 silver coins dated between the Roman Republic and Hadrian (AD 117-138).
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
More than 800 originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 441 coins: 406 sestertii, 29 dupondii, 5 asses, 1 AE provincial: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (443 coins); Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (1 coin).

summary: Hoard of 171 denarii, only 139 were recorded: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum Complex Iași, Romania (121 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (50 coins)

summary: Originally 30 denari, 29 preserved: Nerva - Commodus (AD 179-191); silver weight: 78.54 g.
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
(25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Group of 2 dupondii: Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II (Diva) (AD 175-180).
Hoard of 15 imperial denarii found with a jug in an inhumation grave: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.
9 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 128-130).

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The three denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: Six silver coins minted in Caesarea of Cappadocia: Nerva, Trajan 2, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius. According to Pachomov they are coming from a destroyed burial ground. a plausible hypothesis as Kropotkin (2005) mentioned other similar coins found in graves (p. 267; nos. 1927, 1928, 1944).
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.no. 84974)

summary: Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
764 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111). Together were found four silver earrings and 3 silver bracelets found in a ceramic vessel.
disposition: Regional History Museum Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos M II 3331-4094 (764 coins)

summary: 1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.
368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: 35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: 7 aurei: 6 Hadrian, 1 Sabina (AD 132-134)
disposition: Museum of Iron Gates Region Drobeta-Turnu Severin, Romania

summary: In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly one hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and one of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.

Over 300 denarii, only 8 coins were seen: Antoninus Pius 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II), Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla).
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).

In 1931, 14 bronze coins (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found on the surface in front of the southern gate of the Roman fort, which were oxidised together in a clump. Some specimens show exposure to fire.
76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised either a) a ceramic vessel containing several hundred sestertii of Nero to Marcus Aurelius. b) two ceramic vessels found on separate occasions containing 60 and 110 coins respectively.
Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.

Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: 83 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
14 denarii: Domitian 3; Nerva 3; Trajan 6; uncertain (Domitian or Trajan) 1; Hadrian 1 (AD 117-138).
Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).
The hoard comprised 13 provincial tetradrachms dated between AD 60-61 and AD 107-110.
Over 600 sestertii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Around 1,460 denarii - a number established based on an average weight of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: 53 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 156-157).
disposition: Zemaljski muzej Bosne i Hercegovine (National Museum of Bosnia and Herzegovina) Sarajevo (32 coins) - 1981

summary: The hoard comprised between 150 and 175 bronze coins 'mostly of the Early Empire'. One coin bears the effigy of Faustina II
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
378 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.

A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 4 coins were documented: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Commodus.
Two aurei of Vespasian and Trajan, probably, found in Braga.
Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).
20 sestertii, found on a small plate with ashes: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-187).
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.

Eighteen Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). Two additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a ten-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal bones.
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
The hoard comprised a 'vessel containing 60 aurei, of which 17 were bought by the Cabinet des Médailles and 2 by the Musée de Rouen, although neither acquisition can be found today.'

During the excavation of the native British site at Hengistbury Head, over 3000 coins were found lying on the surface and all through the soil. They had evidently been deposited in bundles. Of these over 100 were Roman, the earliest about 91 BC and the latest six coins of Antoninus Pius (138-61 AD). The rest were all British, consisting approximately of 1,300 of the Hengistbury cast type. Of the south-western struck type there were about 1,660. The remainder were various Gaulish, British and Channel Island types with a few new varieties. A coin with EISV on it was the only inscribed specimen.
disposition: British Museum (part); Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Museum (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the contents of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
Around 800 denarii of wchich 189 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.
31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: Seven aurei found in grave no. 7: Nero 2, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius 2, Faustina II (AD 161-180).
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
Hoard of an unknown number of Roman imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii produced some information: Augustus 1, Nero 2, Hadrian 1, 1 broken.
73 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
The hoard comprised 22 aurei (70 ca.-158-159 AD) found most likely between the West Bank, Upper Galilee and the Golan.
The hoard comprised more than a hundred copper alloy coins of Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and Commodus.
10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.

The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.
Hoard containing, among others, an aureus of Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva) and an imitation of Tiberius aureus.

The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel, which was recovered in fragments and comprised 228 denarii. Part of the hoard (estimated at 58 coins) was sold but the landowner kept 200 or 201 denarii from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); weight, c. 80 g.
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a stone. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the antonine dynasty.
About 700 Roman coins were found in a ford in the river Pettarel near Carlisle in 1762. Coins seem to range from Nero to Faustina. A list of 64 of them (1 aureus, 62 denarii and 1 sestertius) exists.
Unknown initial number of coins. 22 denarii: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 139)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest

summary: 101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
Originally 390, 371 preserved: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 965.17 g.
Seven aurei: Vespasian - Hadrian. No further information.
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of coins. 46 coins of Nerva and 31 of Hadrian were in possession of the antiquarian Fornier.
141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).
115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.
A Regensburg employee submitted 8 sestertii (Antoninus Pius to Commodus) to the prehistorical state collection. The coins were derived from a find of unknown size in Regensburg.
41 Alexandrian bronze coins: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 164-165). Found during excavations .
disposition: Exhibited in London 1902, now in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).

96 coins: 10 silver denarii, 1 quinarius, the other 85 coins are copper asses, dupondii and sestertii, and 1 unknown copper denomination. Other finds include 18 wire fibulae, a fragment of a bracelet and 1 unidentified artefact. Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 138-180).
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).
The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: 300 denarii: Augustus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
Hoard of 17 aurei. Only two are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.
A group of 27 coins, together with a further silver coin fragment. Addenda of 3.
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.
16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
(2820) 2819 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.no. 1867

summary: The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
322 denarii are issued from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 193-195).
(10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).

The hoard comprised 2,077 bronze coins along with bronze implements and scrap from a bronze foundry. Mostly quandrantes and semisses but also including Greek provincial, Greek, Republican up to 5th century AD
disposition: Heberden Coin Room, AShmolean Museum, Oxford, Great Britain

summary: The hoard comprised 'approximately 60 sestertii, mostly illegible. 10 identifiable examples were of Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II), Commodus and perhaps, Didius Julianus' Archives of Musée de Rouen. Communication by Mme. Aubin (28.11.1982)

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.
A hoard of 52 denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius) and 1 drachm of Amisus, found during the breaking up of soil in Lausitz. The hoard might have been associated with a series of 7 cremation graves.

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: Four denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found at Aitnock fort (an Iron Age fort), situated on the summit of a cliff which rises about 60 feet perpendicularly from the waters of the Rye stream at the south-west angle of Hindog Glen near Dalry in Ayrshire. The coins had been wrapped in some material and were found in a layer of occupation.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).
25 silver denarii were found along with a considerable amount of human bone, interpreted as being an indicator of a battlefield site.
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: 46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).

A hoard of 200-300 mainly gold coins (Claudius - Hadrian), found while digging peat in Gustorf in 1838/1839. Several finders are reported. Some coins were bought by the Berlin Münzkabinett (16 gold, 2 silver and 3 bronze coins).
A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.
27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 40 coins entered the museum collection in Sofia: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. X

summary: The hoard comprised 9 aurei from Antoninus Pius to Marcus Aurelius.
81 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while building a new house: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.

The hoard comprised 4 sestertii ranging from Trajan to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1957) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 2 coins preserved, but descriptions of all of them exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (2 coins); lost (2 coins)

summary: (?) 3 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
Hoard of at least 62 denarii. Only 13 are known: 8 republican among which Julius Caesar 1, Augustus 3, Hadrian 2.
Around 600 denarii; Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: In 1906, there were 355 coins in the Coin Room of the Royal Academy in Königsberg, 16 copies in the Museum of Prussia, Königsberg. The fate of the rest is unknown. Approximately 250 denars were melted down. Lost

summary: A 'valuable find of gold and silver coins', of which one coin was a denarius of Antoninus Pius (broken and much defaced), found on Dewsbury Moor, near remains of two Roman querns.
19 asses found within one square meters: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 177).
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: Two medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were seven bronze tintinnabula, one patera, and two iron objects.
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

The hoard comprised a vessel containing more than 200 coins. 13 were shown to the local archaeological society: 6 were 'frustes', 6 of the Antonine family (including Faustina I and II) and one depicted a wolf. Bizeul states that they were all coins of the High Empire. Sanquer suggested that the coin depicting a wolf was a fourth century nummus, but reverse types of the Antonine period also depict the wolf. The three coins of Antoninus Pius and 2 of Faustina given to the museum by Gauja 'found in Rezé in 1851' are likely to come from this hoard. The hoard was found during the building of the east-west road through the city.
37 sestertii found during rescue excavations. 32 coins were found in a ceramic jug and 5 next to it: Vespasian - Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius) (AD 180).
A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).
64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Possibble hoard of unknown number of silver and bronze coins found within a cemetery. The only preserved coins are two denarii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120210: 1-2

summary: Hoard of 6 Roman coins, most likely denarii, including: Vespasian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
42 denarii, ranging from Nero to Didius Julianus. It is unsure whether three antoniniani (1 Gallienus, 2 Probus) and 1 denarius of Elagabalus were part of the hoard as well.

The hoard was found in a grave in the Gallo-Roman cemetery. A red ceramic urn was discovered, alongside a small bronze box containing a gold finger ring with glass setting and three aurei of Nero, Domitian and Antoninus Pius. It is not altogether clear whether the coins were found in the box or the urn.

The circumstances of discovery and the composition of the hoard were judged to be suspect. De Vesly questioned whether this hoard might actually have been stolen and assembled as a hoard. However, there is nothing to support this hypothesis. Found by a workman in a quarry in the Duclair forest: Nero - Hadrian (AD 125-128). Two or four coins are missing.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.
Hoard of 104 denarii (317.79g): Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192). There is no information on the no. of coins per issuer.
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).

Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
70 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 6 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (2 Trajan, 1 Hadrian), Thessalonica (1 Trajan, 1 pseudo-autonomous Antoninus Pius), found in grave 7 in Sevasti.
A hoard of 30 denarii and 1 as (Republic - Trajan) found by the west wall of a plaster layer during an excavation on Reismühler Straße.

Three denarii (1 of Trajan and 2 of Septimius Severus that share the same obverse die) from the same context (C/26/34), that may represent a small hoard, found at Kifrin, a large fortified settlement with Parthian and Roman phases of the 2nd and 3rd c. AD, on the east bank of the Euphrates.
11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
A bronze jug containing 160 aurei, found on site 29 in Corbridge. Two bronze coins were found filling the narrow neck of the jug, where they had been placed, to act as a stopper to the narrow neck.
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: 107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn

The hoard comprised numerous copper-alloy vessels, a mirror, a folding seat, Samian ware cups and plates and six glass bottles, one of which contained 40 very worn sestertii and dupondii of Nerva, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina II.

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: 2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Regional museum, Chrudim, Czech Republic (now, missing)

summary: (49) 48 denarii: 35 republican, 13 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 101/102) .
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.

A hoard of 420 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius, found near Alma Wood, Londonthorpe, together with fragments of the base of a small grey flagon which judging from its size and the marks of corrosion on the inside had originally contained the whole hoard. –A.J. White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: 199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.

A hoard of 161 aurei and 4 denarii was discovered on the site of 29 Klagenfurter Str. in Villach. Four aurei were initially discovered before a supervised excavation at the site uncovered the rest of the coins. Of the 161 aurei, only 100 issues dating from Nero to Septimius Severus have been properly catalogued. The four denarii have all been catalogued: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197).
disposition: Museum Der Stadt Villach (115 aurei and 4 denarii); private collection (42 aurei)

summary: Unknown number of denarii. Only two of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: Originally 3 denarii (Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, imitation) found within an Iron Age settlement together iron, earthenware, bone artefacts.

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: 2 aurei of Domitian and Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
At least 1381. Uncertain if all the coins belong to this hoard or they are contaminated from NIETULISKO MAŁE 1: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
disposition: State Archaeological Museum, Wrasaw, Archaeological and Ethnographical Museum, Łodz; Museum in Ostrowiec Świętokrzyskie, Archaeological Museum in Krakow

summary: 3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
The hoard comprised approximately 10 tetradrachms and 35 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
Hoard of 190 denarii found with ceramic vessel: Republic (?) - Hadrian.
Group of 3 coins: Domitian denarius, Trajan denarius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
Report in BM file with information from Suffolk county Council on a group of 7 or 8 coins, only three readily identifiable. Details of the latter only were received.
20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).
52 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 135.15 g.
The hoard apparently comprised 68 denarii, although the catalogue gives a total of 59 coins.

12 coins listed as 'loosely associated with the hoard' from Cadeby in CHRB (no. 2519) and said to have been found 60-80 yards away. These were treated as a separate Treasure Trove case so an additional entry has been created here. They may have been part of another scattered hoard.
The hoard was found on the West of "Blanche-Fontaine" district. A worker discovered an amphora with 1000 aurei, only 164 are now recorded from Augustus to Hadrian.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).
50 denarii found in the debris from a house foundation: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169).
disposition: Kärntner Landsmannschaft, Klagenfurt, Austria (46 coins); private collection (2 coins), lost (unknown number)

summary: Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
5 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 14.16 g.

Two denarii of Antoninus Pius, the first 'found on the Laleston by-pass road behind (SE. of) the Mackworth Inn', the second 'found during road widening on the Cardiff-Swansea road, near the A.A. Box west of Laleston'. One might suspect that both coins came from the same hoard, scattered by workmen somewhere near Laleston.
The hoard comprised an unknow number of aurei, at least 12(?), from Vespasian to Hadrian (AD 136).
8 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius, found on the north bank of the Tay at Inchyra, east of Perth.
Hoard of around 50 denarii. 21 coins were brought for examination by the finder: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
33 bronze coins found together in one insula of the former Roman city of Baetulo.

Two groups of coins, discovered in May 1989 while metal detecting on building ground at Elphinstone Road, Hastings. The first group of coins (92 bronze coins, Nero - Hadrian) were found with the remains of a pot and the second group (52 denarii found 'in a lump', with 7 later addenda, Republic - Hadrian) was about 40 to 50 feet away from the first. This may suggest successive deposits but they were treated as one find at the time. They have been split here. This record is for the silver coins.
189 denarii: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași (134 coins), History Museum "lulian Antonescu", Bacău (21 coins), History Museum, Onești (13 coins); Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra-Neamț (22 coins)

summary: 85 denarii: Nerva - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
(3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: 22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
A hoard of Roman denarii comprising at least 47 coins ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
6 denarii to AD 161 - "hoard 2" Davies 2000. From an occupation layer in range 3 of structure 1, Pickfords Garage site. Scattered in a small area with no evidence of a container.
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five denarii are known: Tiberius - Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.
The hoard was found during excavations and comprised two piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.

The hoard comprised 4 coins including one earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and two Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of at least 46 denarii: Nero – Commodus (AD 180-192). Possible, part of the hoard from Strunga.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (25 coins)

summary: (8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: Unknown number of bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus/Pertinax (AD 193).

A hoard of 10 aurei and 120+ denarii, found in 1878 near the Roman fort. The closure date of this hoard is AD 192. However the penultimate coin is an issue of 185 and a seven year gap between the terminal issues is unusual. In the event the hoard is listed as closing with RIC 241, with the caveat that the last coin may be a site find rather than a hoard item (P.J. Casey).

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: 12 denarii entered the collection of the Pedagogic High-School in Iași: Vitellius – Hadrian (AD 125-128). Part of the hoards Strunga I and II.
21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
38 bronze coins: 2 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 28 asse, 4 dupondii or asses: Titus - Commodus (AD 192).
Around 142 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Friends of Science Society, Poznań, Poland (143 coins)

summary: 14 denarii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177); silver weight: 38.41 g.

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.
55 bronze coins with unknown findspot except for the mention north Portugal
12 coins: 1 denarius, 11 sestertiiTrajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found 800 m westward from the hoard Koropie 2008 1. Together were found a bronze brooch and a horn shape bronze ring
disposition: Laboratory of Archeology, Historical Sociology and Cultural Heritage, Faculty of Sociology, St. Petersburg State University, Russia

summary: Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
Unknown initial number of denarii. 27 coins provide information on issuers: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

summary: 10 denarii found on a field: Trajan - Commodus (AD 186-187); silver weight: 26.87 g.
12 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 125-127).
Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
In 1857/8 at least 11 denarii ranging from Vespasian to Hadrian were found during building work in the basement of a house.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 20 denarii were documented: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (Crispina (AD 161-180).
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: 13 Roman silver coins, presented to the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland, in 1781, all dug up 'with a great many more' in the muir (= moorland) of Linlithgow. These probably came from a find of 300, found in the Burrowmuir, deposited in an earthen urn.
The hoard comprised 31 tetradrachms, 17 denarii, and 7 bronze coins from the Bar Kohba Revolt (AD 132-136) and one denarius of Trajan.

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millstone by workmen removing "a quantity of loose stones and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only one lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard(?) comprised a "cluster" of 13 silver and bronze coins deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: 116 coins - 3 aurei and 113 denarii - found together during the archaeological excavations
