The coins were found in a glass urn along with a human cremation. Among issuers Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 185 coins, deposited during the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: The hoard comprised 10 bronze coins: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111). Weight: 68.27 g.
disposition: Soprintendenza per i Beni Archeologici del Veneto, Padova, Italy

summary: A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"
Around 1,200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
Five denarii (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of the Buchow-Karpzow estate, probably only part of a larger find.
The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.
The hoard comprised 117 sestertii and 43 dupondii or asses from Vespasian to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. It was found under the sixth step of a staircase discovered under a lime kiln.
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 270.19 g. (100 coins).
50 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Commodus Augustus) (AD 177-178). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 1, practically, one hoard.
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.

15 Roman gold coins described in the Madras Museum Accessions Register as 'purchases through individuals through the Collector of Canara'. It is unclear whether rhey represent a genuine hoard. Possible part of the cache of Roman coins dating from the first and second centuries A.D. was reportedly discovered some 600 kms. further to the north, on Kadmat Island in the neighbouring Laccadives group (Indian Union Territory of Lakshadweep) during 1948
15 denarii: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: 22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: 92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
188 bronze coins fund in a ceramic vessel: 151 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 4 dupondii/asses, 17 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).

The hoard (4 coins, Republic - Faustina I/II) was found with around 20 coins in 1772 during the digging of a draw well in front of the castle. - not sure which castle is meant, as there are three of them in Jagsthausen.
Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: The deposit was found at the major Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary site at comprised three asses from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 164.
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology and Ethnology, Łódź, Poland (2 coins)

summary: 10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.

Penhallurick 2009, 269: "The museum on St Mary's has three sestertii found in a midden layer on the southern shoreline of Tean in 1956. Accompanying pottery indicated an occupation from the first to the fourth centuries and included sherds of samian ware and a bronze brooch (Thomas 1985, p.183)". He notes that the second sestertius of Marcus Aurelius listed here may have been turned into a brooch (bronze adhered to the bottom of the reverse), though this has not been verified.

A number of coin finds were made during controlled archaeological excavation by Wessex Archaeology at the RLE sites Springhead Roman Town (RLE Event Code ARC SPH00) and Springhead Nursery (ARC SHN02) as part of the programme of archaeological works undertaken in advance of the construction of the Channel Tunnel Rail Link (now known as HS1), between 2000 and 2003.
Unknown initial number of coins. 1,481 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. M I 453-1933

summary: (Circa 86) 14 aurei: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282)? Found together with 2 gold bracelets, 2 gold earrings, 1 Gold chain.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (10 aurei)

summary: Hoard found during ploughing, 200 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).

A hoard of ca. 3220 Roman silver coins (denarii and antoniniani), ranging from Antoninus Pius to Postumus, found in a vessel during works at the Erthalstraße in 1886. Some of the hoard was dispersed. 1872 coins are listed in FMRD.
Five denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Septimius Severus, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

2,154 silver coins: 45 denarii, 2,109 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260); + 6,669 provincial bronzes: 3,600 Callatis, 3,000 Tomis, 6 Histria, 5 Odessos, 21 Marcianopolis, 13 Nicopolis, 8 Hdrianopolis, 6 Anchialos, 3 Dionysopolis, 3 Mesembria, 1 Pautalia, 1 Bizantion, 1 Augusta Traiana, 1 Nicaea.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 44 provincial coins have been noticed from mints of Lower Moesia and Thrace: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 193-2244).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLXXXII (7 coins)

summary: 3 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), but this is not certain. Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
14 sestertii: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 9 aurei, some gold jewellery and a jet amulet. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 45.4-46.0g. The entire hoard was acquired by Dr. E. Poncet for his private collection.

The surviving part of the hoard includes 164 denari and 118 antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasianus to Philip I (AD 72-248). 221 coins are now kept in the Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale, 61 in different private collections. The original amount of the hoard remains unknown. Given the very little distance between the two findspots, Masi I and Masi II should be two sections of the same hoard deposited in different places by its owner.
disposition: Pordenone, Museo Archeologico del Friuli Occidentale

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 604 coins were catalogued. TAF outlines the numbers of coins by emperor and by mint but the two sets of figures do not tally. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 116.4g and 1097.6g.
33 tedrachams from Philip I (Otacilia Severa) - Diocletian. Before the monetary reform of AD 297. Only 16 pieces could be identified.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only three antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus' joint reign and Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269. FMRL suggests that it was a small part of a much larger hoard.
17 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 sestertius (separated): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
Unknown originally number of coins. 53 denarii were recovered in two lots: Vespasian – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.
151 antoniniani: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Local museum Govora, Vâlcea County, Romania (1966); Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (101 coins spread through the coin collection)

summary: 3,256 coins, mainly antoniniani radiates, together with nummi and an argenteus found in a ceramic vessel: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetrarchy (AD 285-298).

The hoard comprised 59 coins, including one denarius of Maximinus and 58 Roman Provincial coins, found in a grave on the north side of the hill of the « Παλαιόν Ηρώον ». The coins of the Koinon are inscribed ΚΟΙΝΟΝ ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ and ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ ΟΜΟΝΟΙΑ.
The hoard comprised approximately 500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I and Postumus and three bronze coins: 1 Lucilla, 1 Maximinus I Thrax, 1 Postumus (sestertii?) (AD 260-269).

The original find comprised 5578 coins, of which only 2,330, including 7 ancient forgeries, were recovered by the authorities. These can divided into two lots; first, 1067 denarii from Vespasian to Macrinus/Elagabalus (217/22), second, 1263 antoniniani from Severus Alexander to Gallienus (260/8).
40 asses and sestertii. 18 coins entered the collection Gerville: 1 Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius, 16 Postumus.
Sometime before 1869, somewhere in the vicinity of Nantes, a hoard comprising several hundreds antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II was discovered.
16 silver coins: 4 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of 25 aurei (Faustina I - Trajan Decius), one medallion of Gallienus and 16 articles of jewellery, found at Octavian Augustus Street in the ancient Jewish quarter in Alexandria.

A hoard of Roman bronze coins, next to a few gold ones, found during the construction of the railrepair workshop in Neustadt. It was acquired by the museum in three successive lots (A-C: 26 coins, 5 coins, 1 coin).
126 sestertii: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).

Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel within a necropolis. Together with the cois a scarbee gem was found in the same vessel. Only three coins were identified: Faustina II, Septimius Severus, Elagabalus.
The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: (c. 100) 81: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 51.3-104.7 g.
A hoard of 21 badly corroded provincial bronze coins, dating from Septimius Severus to Gordian III, found in Dura Europos.
Unknown number of silver and provincial bronze coins. 100 silver coins were seen: Pertinax - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Ruse: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 1-43

summary: The hoard was found in a small square cairn created with Roman tiles stuck together with red Roman cement and was surrounded by numerous stone sarcophagi. It comprised 87 sestertii from Vespasian to Gordian III and an oculist's stamp inscribed with the name C. TITTIVS BALBINVS.
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing a gold finger ring, a silver bracelet and 28 coins from Marcus Aurelius to Valerian I.
201 sestertii from Domitian to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 254-255).

The hoard comprised around 1500 silver coins (532 known). The known pieces belong to Trebonianus Gallus (518) and Volusianus (14). The coins had been acquired in Antakya and were said to be a local find.
2826 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 2824 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

Large hoard of denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Uncertain composition due to the complex story about the real number of hoards found in this area and how the finders split the finds. Denarii from Nero to Septimius Severus (AD 202). Based on the catalog from TIR M 34, pp. 157-180, it contained 3,170 silver coins: 3,169 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla (Augustus)) (AD 202).

A hoard of 1925 denarii (Republic - Severus Alexander), found during levelling operations in the area of Bell's Meadow, in Falkirk, ca. 400 m NW of the Antonine Wall, in a vessel of red earthenware. A piece of cloth had been used to protect the mouth of the vessel. A few coins were lost, but all others passed into the hands of the Crown Authorities as treasure-trove. In all, 1925 coins, comprising 1923 denarii, one drachm of Lycia, and one bronze core of a plated denarius, were examined and published in 1934 by G. MacDonald. A new list, based on visual examination of the preserved coins, is given by Robertson, Studia Paulo Naster Oblata (1982). The latter recorded only 1917 coins. The missing coins were 2 denarii of Vespasian, 1 of Domitian, 2 of Trajan, 1 of Antoninus Pius, 1 of Diva Faustina I, and one of Septimius Severus. Recent studies have shown that 3 of the denarii attributed by Sir George Macdonald to Caracalla should be assigned to Elagabalus.
disposition: NMAS, Edinburgh (pot, cloth frag. and most of the 1925 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,968 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). 1,862 of these coins were identifiable (219 denarii and 1,643 antoniniani (radiates) and form the basis of a catalogue by Le Gentilhomme (1946). The current hoard catalogue outlined here needs checking against this original publication.
Unknown number of silver coins. 50 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2391, 50 coins

summary: 7 bronze coins finds found in excavations: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. no. 59/1-5

summary: (c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.

The hoard comprised an amphora containing 1,400 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus (AD 269-271). A catalogue exists for 1,335 antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 421g and 1,749g.
3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

A hoard of 1,702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1,702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.
200 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 100 pieces were recovered: 92 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: History Museum, Caracal (17 coins); Museum of Oltenia, Craiova (83 coins), Romania

summary: 3,000 coins: Septimius Severus – Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (unknown number of coins)

summary: (1900) 1898 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256-257); silver weight: 1324.4-2705.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. no. 923 1-248

summary: (896) 890 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (Ad 251-253).
83 eastern antoniniani (radiates) ranging in date from the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian.
A suspicious hoard as there is no evidence for the conditions of discovery, except one note in a local newspaper: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (Plautilla (AD 202-205).

At least three aes coins (Domitian and Gallienus), along with numerous other finds, including a tombstone, mortarium, glassware, fibulae, and studs, discovered while digging the foundations of the new gaol (now HMP Usk) on the field known as 'Cae Puta'. The two radiates of Gallienus might constitute a hoard, but the addition of the single aes of Domitian throws this into doubt. In lieu of more accurate information concerning their context, it is just as likely that all three are single finds instead of a hoard. Nash-Williams (1928) speculated that the site might have been the location of a fort.
1,739 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 18 coins are kept in the Hungarian National Museum in Budapest: Augustus – Gordian III (AD 243-244)

The hoard consists of 336 coins, most of which are separate, with some bunches of coins stuck together. Additionally, there are eight fragments of pottery, including the complete base of the ceramic vessel with some coins still intact. Most coins are clearly contemporary copies or 'barbarous radiates'.
Unnown initial number of coins. 35 silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 45.1-89.5 g.

The hoard was found in a black ceramic vessel placed within a pit lined with four tiles. It comprised approximately 4,000 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Tetricus I and II. Issues of Gallienus and Claudius II were the most numerous. A small portion of the hoard including 103 coins were catalogued.
Unknown initial number of coins. 17 silver coins entered the museum collection in Stara Zagora: 2 denarii, 15 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 245-247); silver weight: 22.0-42.3 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 3240-3246

summary: 60 antoniniani (radiates) found with remains from a textile bag: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270) in a doctor house.
Before 1889, 8 coins were found in a garden in Campbon. These included one radiate of Tacitus and 2 of Probus. They may represent a portion of a larger hoard.
Four antoniniani (radiates), that may have belonged to a hoard: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius for Hostilian (Caesar/Augustus), Gallienus (AD 253-259).
Around thirty antoniniani in freshly minted condition, of Gallienus, Macrianus, and other contemporaneous issuers.
631 Roman imperial bronze coins: Trajan (Plotina) - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver weight: 203.3-1735.5g.
872 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 632.6-2244.5g
23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2678, 23 coins

summary: 18 (?) silver coins, found 1925 on the street 'Am Römerwall'. 21 coins are mentioned in the inventory of the Altermusmuseum, but the coins are now lost.
9 coins found near a broken money-box: 5 antoniniani, 2 denarii, 1 sestertius, 1 unidentified denomination: Septimius Severus/Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
Hoard found with pot: 19 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates), 4 sestertii: Marcus Aurelius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).

A hoard of 180+ AE provincial coins of Thrace (1), Macedonia (2) and Asia Minor (177, mostly Pamphylia (64), Pisidia (50) and Western Cilicia (10)), dating from the first century AD to the reign of Aurelian.
3503 radiates to Probus, in a pot. Full identifications of all the coins of Probus is unavailable. Unpublished?

In 1953 a hoard was salvaged between Jahn and Gerhart-Hauptmannstraße. Only part of the hoard could be saved. Coins include 87 denarii, sestertius and dupondii, ranging from Nero (?) to Severus Alexander.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a copper-alloy finger ring, two gold finger rings, one with an engraved intaglio setting and 2,334 denarii and radiates from Antoninus Pius to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 702.5g to 6042.8g.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 2,000 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Only 701 coins were catalogued. Note that for Gallienus, Valerian II, Saloninus, Salonina and Postumus, mints are given according to RIC (Lyon), not Elmer (Cologne).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,507 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275); weight: 6,100 kg.
The hoard comprised approximately 50 silver coins (almost certainly radiates) from Gordian III to Gallienus.
8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.

The hoard comprised 57 bronzes dating to the second and third century AD. Sherds of pottery were recovered at the same time as the hoard suggesting that it was originally stored in a vessel. The hoard was discovered in a molehill. Although mentioned in numerous publications, it has never been studied in any detail. It was kept by the Club archéologique d'Auzances.
Hoard of 1,040 silver coins (?) found in a small ceramic vessel of which only 394 silver coins are known: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Museum, Panagyurishte; Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria

summary: 10 denarii and 1 sestertius: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 15.6-28g.
The hoard comprised c. 1,500 coins from Valerian I to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
A hoard of 1,545 coins (270 tetradrachms, 1 bronze, 1,274 antoniniani down to Claudius II, AD 270), found during the excavations at Capharnaeum.
Unknown number of coins. 4 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 1 denarius Maximinus I Thrax, 3 antoniniani : 1 Caracalla, 2 Gordian III.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2591

summary: During the excavations of 1890, a hoard of 170 bronze coins were discovered: 169 sestertii and 1 provincial bronze: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
109 denarii and antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 134.3-277.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1841

summary: This find comprised two hoards, found several days apart in neighbouring fields. The first, comprised a grey coarseware vessel containing approximately 2,300 antoniniani (radiates). The second comprised a red ceramic jug containing at least 32 antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 622 and 2874g.
The hoard includes 6 denari and 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Philip I (AD 103-247) kept in a private collection.
This hoard of twenty three coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.
6 aurei: Elagabalus - Carinus (AD 283-285).
745 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 293).
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: The hoard comprised 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
437 antoniniani (radiates) in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Musées royauc d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: The total number of coins originally found is unknown. There are two catalogues which slightly vary in the numbers of coins present. The one in May 1968 is entered here: Claudius II (Divus) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown silver coins. 45 coins were bought by the museum in Traismauer. One of the coins is an anotninianus of Probus.
HER has a record of "a hoard of 22 antoniniani of the period AD259-273" in Swindon Museum.
Over 2,897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: 5 bronze coins found in room 42 of the 'Gordian's Palace': Antoninus Pius 1 sestertius, Faustina II 1 sestertius, 1 as/dupondius, Gordian III 2 sestertii.
Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
35 antoniniani (radiates), 28 seen: Marius - Tetricus (AD 271-274); silver weight: c.10.5 g.
The hoard comprised 105 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 bronze issues and was apparently deposited c. AD 263. No reasons are given for this date for deposition.
Around 600 silver coins, of which 432 were seen: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
(5000+) 14 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274)
860 billon tetradrachms: Marcus Aurelius - Claudius II (AD 268-269) found during excavations beneath the floor of an underground room of a house.
disposition: 849 in Ann Arbor. The rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the thirty tyrants' (AD 260-274).

A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.

The hoard was found deposited in an old wall and comprised 838 antoniniani (radiates). Hucher compiled a catalogue of 810 coins: Trajan Decius - Postumus (AD 260-269). Hucher acquired 351 coins for the Musée du Mans (Manuscript of entries 1863-1909, p. 4 and 5) and the Hospice kept 487 coins.Silver weight: 227.2-1046.5 g.
The hoard comprised an urn containing approximately 700 base-silver coins, which were not described in any detail. TAF suggests that this was a hoard of antoniniani (radiates).
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii from Titus to Gordian III.
Four gold coins found in a female grave: Septimius Severus 2, Philip I and Valerian I (AD 253-260).
The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
Over 3,000 billon coins of Alexandria offered for sale in Cairo to Dattari. "Many Aurelianus, some Claudius and perhaps 1/4 Gallienus." Yje sale did not take place.
The hoard comprised more than 36,000 coins, probably all antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel on the area of an a ancient settlement. 85 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2237

summary: Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 117 entered the museum collection in Sliven: 84 antoniniani, 33 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 157.2-281.4 g.

A farmer from Unter-Horgen found a hoard while fertilizing a marshy pasture. During this work he saw a number of coins laying next to a vessel in a ditch. The hoard comprised possibly up to 600 coins. The list given in FMRD encompasses 274 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Marius.
284 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further information.
76 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 18.9-30.0g.
The workers discovered a metallic vase with 20 kg of coins (maybe antoniniani). Only 214 are now recorded, from Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland (part of the hoard)

summary: 156 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 143 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 8 asses; silver weight: 6.4-8.6g.
49 coins: 3 silver and 46 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2100-2148 (49 coins)

summary: Two ceramic vessels containing over 8,500 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard was found in small red brick 'ampoule' in a grave next to a skeleton. It comprised 307 radiates from Valerian I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270.
147 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269).
The find of Adlerterrain in 1903 comprised twelve antoniniani and denarii ranging from Maximinus Thrax to Gallienus.
2669 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 721.6-3335.3 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLVII

summary: (c. 1500) 64 antoniniani (radiates): 8 genuine, 56 copies: Valerian I (Salonina) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: c. 390.0 g.
115 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing a silver finger ring with blue glass setting depicting a figure left and 380 radiates from Gordian III to Postumus. 267 examples were catalogued by Pinsard. A closing date of AD 268 is given by a APOLLINI CONS AVG reverse of Gallienus and 7 coins of Postumus with ORIENS AVG with P in the field reverses.
The composition of this hoard was reconstructed by Paul Reinecke. The coins (10 denarii, ranging from Galba to Maximinus) were found in a wood belonging to the abbey at Metten, soon after 1800.
600 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269). Found close to the hoard ETTELBRÜCK 1889. Silver: 592 coins; Silver weight: 161.1-740.3g.
1980 antoniniani: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 535.6-2474.0 g.

The hoard comprised 29 coins, ranging from Hellenistic times (?) to Philip. This includes coins of Athens and Cnossus, as well as Roman sestertii, dupondii and asses. Hadrian, Severus Alexander and Gordian III are also mentioned. The hoard was found beneath the foundations of a building, under a slab of stone.
216 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 215 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 242-244); silver weight: 303.1-491.4 g.
32 antoniniani (radiates) belonging to a purse: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Museum Lauriacum - Museum der Stadt Enns, Austria

summary: 43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between two large stones.

Found in a gravel pit while digging for gravel, along with potsherds. Located in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Of approximately 1,500 coins, ca. 1,270 are preserved in the Liestal Museum and 756 are issues of the Gallic Empire (Postumus, Victorinus, Tetrici). The coins seem to have been arranged in rolls inside the vessel.

The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 coins 'nearly all with the bust of Augustus' and bearing the reverse type LAETITIA AVG. As the LAETITIA AVG reverse type is most common on issues of Gordian III, under the Gallic Emperors and under Probus, it is likely that the coins were radiates dating to the third century AD.
The hoard comprised 117 bronze coins dated between Ptolemy I (323-283/2 BC) and Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
1200 denarii found in ceramic vessel. 156 pieces entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1072-1142

summary: 265 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228).
12 provincial coins ranging from Commodus to Philip (Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedononia) found in grave 8 in Methone.
Around 500 denarii found in two ceramic vessels. 230 coins provided the issuer: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205).
Hoard of antoniniani (radiates) and denarii. 128 coins were kept in the museum in Modena in 1829: Maximinus I Thrax (Diva Paulina) - Claudius II (AD 268-270).

A hoard of 103 Roman imperial denarii: Otho – Caracalla (AD 211-217) was discovered by two treasure hunters in the mid-October 2009 in the Kyiv region. The first report about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on October 26, 2009, and on October 29, November 2 and 23 photos of the coins were published. According to one of the finders, initially, not far from the unexcavated earlier pits from other treasure hunters, 71 coins were found on an area of 5x5 meters with a depth of 15-20 cm. At a later time, on the findspot was made sondage and the next 19 coins were found, and later – a further 13. The coins were cleaned by finders. The preservation of the coins is mostly good to very good. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
48 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: IARCH record of a hoard of 11 sestertii from Devon. For details see DEV-37EC41.
1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)

75 coins: 73 antoniniani, 1 as, 1 as/dupondius found in a house at an altar, ranging from Domitian/Hadrian to Carinus for Numerian (Augustus) (AD 283-284). The specimens listed here follow Marion's publication, but Thouvenot's inventory differs slightly in that he records two specimens of RIC Gallienus 178, only single specimens of RIC 207 and 28, he omits RIC 36, 45/6 and one illegible specimen for Claudius Gothicus, but instead gives two examples of RIC 48 and another illegible type, and he also mistakes RIC 705 (Antoninus Pius) for a silver coin.
81 bronze coins: 80 sestertii, 1 as: Hadrian - Aemilianus (AD 253).
8,077 antoniniani (radiates) found with a cooking pot: Philip I to Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 1532.5-14662.1g.

The hoard comprised a gold necklace and 20 copper-alloy coins from Commodus and Caracalla. The archive report questions whether this deposit represents a horad but does not provide any further explanation.

On the jaws of a skeleton near the previous one were seven well-preserved coins: one silver by Caracalla; another pure silver by Alessandro Severo; three of Aureliano and one of Caro, covered with silver, and one of copper belonging to Probus.
Hoard of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 78 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Severus Alexander - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2072

summary: A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, five of the nine coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.
18 bronze coins found in a grave: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
14 silver coins: 3 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 257-258); Silver weight: 17.9-30.6 g.
500 coins of which only 16 were seen have been found on the canabae area: Tiberius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
535 antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. No further information.

51 radiates (Volusian to Victorinus) found in the course of excavations at the Cambria House site on the civil settlement outside the legionary fortress at the NW corner. The coins were in the filling of a drain, but it is not clear whether they represent a deliberate deposit or an accidental loss.
The hoard comprised 9 antoniniani (radiates). The emperors represented include Gordian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian I, Gallienus and Salonina. There is no catalogue.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain

summary: 2,329 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 289-290) found in a jar, buried beneath the doorway between a room and the courtyard, during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised 73 denarii from Septimius Severus to Maximinus and 215 radiates from Pupienus to Valerian (AD 253-260). Hobbs estimated a silver weight of between 372.6-693.8g.

The hoard comprised two or three ceramic urns filled with Roman coins, weighing approximately 5 kilos or perhaps 1,200 coins. Although the containers were broken up and the hoard dispersed, 762 coins were recovered in the days following the hoard's discovery, including 10 from the presumed findspot. They were all radiates from Gordian III to Claudius II and Postumus.
2 coins: 1 bronze Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/ Diva Faustina II), 1 antoninianus (radiate) Claudius II (AD 268-270)

In 1927 about 360 denarii and antoniniani (Caracalla - Postumus) were unearthed. The coins were strewn on the ground, on a place located on the floodplain of the river Rhine. There was also half of a longsword, remnants of scissors, 4 bronze rings and 50 tokens of glass and glass base.
Apparently more than 500 coins in this hoard.

543 denarii (of which 5 plated) found with a pitcher: Nero - Macrinus (AD 218); 1768 g. The mints of Alexandria, Antioch and Emesa are represented by one copy each, while the one from Laodicea by a total of 12 coins.

A hoard of 1985 denarii (Nero-Julia Mamaea); 310 drachms of Arabia (242 of which depict Arabia and 68 show a camel, some overstruck on Nabataean kings); 1 Caesarean drachm (Domitian); 31 tetradrachms of Antioch (Nero-Hadrian); 2 Lycian drachms (Trajan); 2 Amisus drachms (Hadrian), found in a village near Amman.
disposition: American Numismatic Society (2333, 2321 of which are still listed in ANS records), American University in Beirut (17)

summary: The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.

Found during excavations in a Gallo-Roman "Vierecktempel" on a hilltop, above a cliff. Among many single finds a depot of 66 antoniniani (latest coin Diocletian, AD 293), found in the cella of the temple.
An unpublished hoard of 3 provincial coins (Dium, Thessalonica and the Koinon of Macedonia) and 4 blanks, from a building within the city.
Part of a larger hoard. 50 silver coins: 13 denarii, 37 antoniniani: Domitian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 64.6-130.2 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3173-3186

summary: 32 coins: 23 sestertii, 7 dupondii and 2 antoniniani (radiates): Titus - Postumus (AD 260-268).
It is not clear whether this hoard forms part of the hoard found within the well in 1869 (See 5528). The vessel contained between 141 and 144 bronze coins from Augustus to Postumus.

Several reports mention several silver coins (probably a hoard) ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found on the Flürener Heide, on a sand hill, close to Diersfordt, Flüren. The coins have been dispersed.

The hoard comprised 67 Provincial coins mostly from local mints (Thessalonica, Macedonian Koinon) of the time of Gordian III, found in a Roman farmhouse located in a field southeast of the provincial road, west of Afytos.
113 coins: Claudius I - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). No information on the denominations or other issuers.

A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as mentioned in Noe).
112 coins: imperial and provincial: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver weight: 217.0-343.5g.

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD. 114 coins lying in a kind of trench, below the bottom of the opening near the stoves, ranging from Gallienus to Carausius.
The hoard comprised one vessel containing 8,760 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelianus. Silver weight: 1664.9-6394.3g.
Unknown initial number of coins. Y. Youroukova have seen 22 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
In a ceramic vessel were found antoniniani from Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). 1,153 coins are kept in the History Museum in Lom. 886 antoniniani belong to Volusian.
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; inv.no. 2470 (1153 coins)

summary: A hoard of 120+ Syrian tetradrachms dating from Caracalla to Trebonianus Gallus.
16 silver coins: 2 denarii, 14 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
18 coins : 13 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
8 coins found in a cave: Antoninus Pius - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II); silver weight: 4.1-13.9g.
119 coins: 1 denarius, 118 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-259).
196 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valentinian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 245.0g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing several thousand (more than 4,000?) coins from Septimius Severus to Postumus 'all in silver, with varying titles'. A list of numbers of types (rather than numbers of coins) exists. The coins were discovered 'by chance' in ancient ruins at the site. Silver: 4000+ (480) coins; Silver weight: 921.7-10397.2+
disposition: Musée d'Orbigny (20 coins), France; Musée de Guéret, France

summary: Unknown number of coins. 4 coins in the museum of Lovech: Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Severus Alexander, Philip II.
Around 800 denarii found with a copper alloy vessel: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard was found in a Gallo-Roman cemetery scattered over an area of some metres and comprised an unknown number of coins. 43 were recovered by private individuals and recorded by FMRL: Valetian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
The total number of coins found is not known although it is suggested to be as 5,000 pieces. Only 251 coins kept in a local collection were studied. Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
3,501 antoniniani: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
6,442 silver coins: 6,395 denarii, 47 antoniniani (radiates): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); weight of 21 kg.
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Philip II "and other emperors and empresses of the 3rd century".
A hoard of 119 antoniniani (radiates) was found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Together were found a silver anchor type brooch and a glass vessel.
4,370 coins found in a cooking pot with graffiti (ME X): 4 denarii, 4,366 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282)
disposition: Centre archéologique de la Mayenne, Jublains, France

summary: It comprised 500 Roman silver and billon coins, of which only 104 were identified dating from the reign of Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius through to Carinus. It is possible that the radiate of Magnia Urbica is an intruder. Besançon mentions a coin of Maximinus Daia, but is an error resulting from confusion with Maximinus of Thrace. The hoard was found few meters from the hoard SAINT-GEORGES-DE-RENEINS 1880.
The hoard comprised 43 radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus. It was found in the same area as Oštra Luka II.
25 provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Hadrianopolis
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1780 1-25

summary: 40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 34 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 3 aurei: Trajan, Septimius Severus, Caracalla (AD 213).
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
It comprised c. 150 sestertii. 145 had been studied from Trajan to Gordian III.
21 aurei of Gordian III (Rome, AD 241-243).

The hoard comprised 202 antoniniani (radiates), placed inside a sandstone altar and found in association with a variety of objects in copper-alloy, iron and ceramic. The latest coin is an issue of Postumus dating to AD 266.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA M II
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.

The hoard comprised between 450 and 500 coins of which only 46 were identified. The coins come from the mints of Rome and Cologne. Found during building work during the German occupation of 1914-1917. The hoard was found a couple of 100 meters from the hoard at Noyelles-Godault (TAF II.57) Silver: 450-500 (45, 1) coins; Silver weight: 129.2-592.8 g.
134 silver coins: 6 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259-260); silver weight: 166.1-340.8 g.
86 of various denominations - sestertii, asses, antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Quintillus (AD 270).

Over 90 coins: antoniniani, provincial bronze medallions, provincial bronze coins: Caracalla - Gordian III (Ad 238-244). Provincial coins were minted in: Pautalia, Serdica, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Deultum, Anchialus.

Before 1939, an archaeologist bought a hoard comprising 2,065 antoniniani (radiates) from a clerk in Évron. The hoard appears to have come from the north of the département, perhaps Aron or Évron, or, according to Cordonnier is another hoard from Jublains: Trajan Decius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
107 denarii, ranging up to AD 227 (Severus Alexander).
disposition: Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle upon Tyne

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing between 1,500 and 1,800 antoniniani (radiates) and 3 sestertii of Divus Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander and Postumus.
152 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 211-217). Circumstances of find not known.
Unknown number of Roman provincial bronze coins were found in unknown circumstances. 38 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22168-22205

summary: 79 denarii and antoniniani were found with a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard comprised somewhere between 2,000 and 2,500 coins, of which a large proportion were taken by the finders. Only 308 coins were catalogued.
3,428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: 101 coins: 21 denarii, 74 antoniniani, 6 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2780

summary: Circa 80 silver coins. Only 2 of Caracalla, 3 of Gordian III, 1 of Philip I are known.
30 coins: 2 sestertii, 28 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).
(36) 34 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip (AD 244-249).

The hoard was found during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' at Troussepoil and comprised 231 brass coins (sestertii?). Close to the hoard, 3 broken black ceramic jugs were excavated, two of which were filled with ashes and funeral pyre debris. Baudry thought that the coins had originally been placed in the jugs, but that hypothesis is not certain. The hoard was discovered during the excavation of 21 'puits funéraire' of Troussepoil.

A farmer from Buprich uncovered an earthenware container filled with many Roman coins in the vicinity of the village. The container appears to have contained more than 1000 antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus). 832 of them were described, but giving only the reverse legend, not the type. 727 are listed in FMRD.

The hoard comprised 119 antoniniani (radiates). However, only 109 are preserved in the Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Tarragona as 10 were lost during successive renovations of the museum: Gallienus - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
Unknown number of coins. 14 provincial bronze coins entered museum collection in Nesebar: Antoninus Pius - Caracalla. Mints: Augusta Traiana, Philippopolis, Hadrianopolis, Serdica, Anchialus
disposition: History Museum, Nesebar, Bulgaria; inv.no. XI

summary: The hoard comprised 5,200, 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramiv vessel: Maximinus I Tharx -Diocletian and Maximian I (before AD 294).

The hoard was found in a funerary casket with an ornate lid decorated with a red marble plaque. The casket contained cremated bone, two small amphorae, a glass vessel, a copper-alloy spatula and 7 dupondii and asses from Tiberius to Severus Alexander.
It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.
Found during excavations in the pars urbana of the Roman villa rustica of Osterfingen, below an ash layer. 18 sestertii, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander, Maximinus Thrax.
39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.
The coins were found during the rescue excavation of a villa: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

On road construction activity a hoard of 300-500 denarii was discovered. Coins of Vespasian, Domitianus, Traianus, Hadrianus, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Septimius Severus and Severus Alexander were noticed.

The hoard comprised 'a lot of bronze and billon coins, of which 83 coins were recovered and give by M. Timbaud to the Musée de Rouen…'it is likely to represent a hoard or a portion of a hoard'; Antoninian dynasty - ; silver weight: 17.6-151.6g.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Museum Inventory III, p. 61, no. 2157 (donated 17.5.1909)

find_spot_name: MADRID - REAL ACADEMIA DE SAN FERNANDO
summary: 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 sestertii 'of 25 emperors, caesars and empresses' from Vespasian to Gordian III, mostly in a corroded or worn condition. There was also a single unworn bronze of Postumus
The hoard was found in pot with 1,600 low-grade silver coins of Postumus. Silver: c.1600 (500) coins; Silver weight: c.432

The hoard comprised 1,300 coins of which 21 from Philip I to Tacitus (AD 275-276) were acquired by C. Quandalle . These are not considered to be representative of the hoard as a whole, being either rare or issues that Quandalle did not have in his collection. Hobbs estimates a silver weight: c. 235.1-1624.1g.
15 bronze coins: 8 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 6 asses: Gaius (Agrippa) – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
disposition: Regional Museum, Hradec Králové, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 2963-2977)

summary: Part of a larger hoard. 17 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1701-1718

summary: Around 1860 a forest warden delivered, among other coins, 6 denarii that lay in rolls, stuck together in a bundle. 7 denarii, ranging from Septimius Severus to Caracalla, were listed among the single finds made in Dambach in 1901 and could be identical with the find made ca. 1860.
Unknown original number of coins. Thre is some scarce information on 23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

The hoard comprised between 800 and 1000 antoniniani/radiates including coins of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Claudius II and Quintillus (AD 270). The exact size of the hoard is not known as the hoard was not preserved as a whole. Found together with a ceramic vessel.
698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 190.0-1811.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (10 coins of Postumus); collection De Bove (34 coins), in 1882

summary: NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late nineteenth century.
The hoard comprised 12 coins of Gallienus and Tetricus I.
Unknown originally number of coins. 30 aurei: Nero - Septimius Severus for Caracalla (Augustus) (AD 202).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel including Roman coins. The hoard was dispersed immediately. The hoard was found during house construction on the site of the church of the Jacobins: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
A hoard comprising 25,000 coins including coins dating from the reign of Gallienus through to Diocletian.
272 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). 6 coins have been lost.

The hoard comprised 26 coins, mostly large bronzes. 13 coins were broken. The others bear the portraits of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucilla. The 4 bronze coins of Postumus are cast and middle size (AD 264-265?).
disposition: Musée Saint-Jean, Angers, France (Reg. II, p. 184, no. 453 bis.)

summary: 60 antoniniani of Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 75 g.
54 silver coins: 26 antoniniani, 28 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 72.6-130.1 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CCXX

summary: The hoard comprised 654 coins of which a total of 444 were recorded. These included 442 denarii from the Republic to Severus Alexander and 2 antoniniani of Caracalla and Elagabalus.
168 denarii and Antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

M. Poilly donated a lot of 173 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) to the Societé archéologique de l'Orléanais' which were found 'in the environs of Dieppe': Maximinus I Thrax - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 44.4-232.4 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. 156 pieces are known of which 39 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius.

The hoard comprised a red ceramic vessel containing between 1,000 and 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) and one denarius. Pilloy saw approximately 300 of these coins and commented that 5/6ths were of Gallienus (particularly his zoo issue) and of Claudius II or Divus Claudius II. The remainder were of Salonina, Quintillus, Victorinus, Aurelian, Severina and Numerian, with the last three authorities represented by one coin each.
The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Aurelian. It is suggested that the coins were the contents of a purse or part of a larger, scattered hoard.

The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins dated between AD 141 and AD 251-253. "The hoard contains a mixture of imperial asses and sestertii, with bronzes from regional 'provincial' mints (Gaza, Ascalon, Caesarea Maritima, Aelia Capitolina, and Nysa-Scythopolis), many of which are countermarked." (Kool, 41).
The hoard comprised 50 to 60 'copper or bronze coins' found with a ceramic vessel. The better preserved pieces included sestertii of Valerian I and Salonina.
The hoard comprised several thousand coins, mostly of Postumus. It is possibly a hoard described as being found in a copper-alloy basin.
4-500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel. 29 coins were studied: Vespasian (Titus Caesar) – Philip I.

Approximately 500 sestertii from Flavian issues to Valerian I found during the construction and landscaping of the military stadium in Cherchell. The hoard was dispersed immediately after discovery, with many being sold to Italian collectors, but some of the coins were acquired by the Collection Bouchereau in Algiers.
191 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian (AD 274-275) found in a pile at floor level in room during excavations of a house. 1 bronze coin of the Ptolemy V may be regarded as a intruder?
The hoard was found in a cemetery and comprised 339 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Diocletian (AD 293).
Six silver coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring and a bracelet: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

A farm laborer found a Roman coin hoard in a plot of a field in Lochhausen, 10 cm below the surface. The hoard contained approx. 1700 antonianini, of which 1675 specimens could be recorded. Part of the hoard was housed in the coin collection at Munich, but lost during the years of war. The list given in FMRD is based on the publication of hoard by M. Bernhardt in 1911. Unfortunately, this publication contains many mistakes and it is not any more possible to give an exact description of the content.

Unknown initial number of silver coins. According to some information from a private collector the number of coins was between 2,500 and 3,000. 26 coins entered museum collection in Sofia: Otho - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 32865

summary: c.50 loose coins and concreted mass weighing 1.8kg· The hoard probably consists of c. 400 ish coins which have corroded into a single concreted mass - the single block weighs approximately 2 kilos and there are another c. 50 loose coins.An organic container was thought likely - traces of leather were found.
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgartenbridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: 6,263 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Rome (4,921); Viminiacum (4); Milan (340), Ticinum (6); Cologne (44); Trier (38); Lyon (2); Siscia (216); Sirmium (2); Antioch (2); Cyzicus (12); uncertain (4); imitations (1,068): Gordian III - Diocletian (AD 287-289). Found during the laying of electrical cables.

A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.

The hoard was found in a cave and comprised 60 Roman coin copies as well as numerous fragments of copper-alloy bar with Roman coin flans stamped on them. The hoard was interpreted as belonging to a forger.
17 antoniniani (radiates). According to Boersma 1967, no. 175, they are dated between AD 253-268. No further information.
A dispersed group of barbarous radiates noted by Penhallurick. Possibly a hoard. The identifiable prototypes are of Tetricus I and II.
16 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 64 sestertii and 77 denarii or antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Valerian I and Gallienus. There was also one gold finger ring and one silver finger ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight between 22.3g and 197.1g
162 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252-253). 'Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".'
(?) 17 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Julia Domna, Gordian III, Valerian I, Gallienus, Claudius II (AD 268-270).

407 silver coins found in two glass bottles. One bottle contained 130 coins, the other 277 pieces: 86 denarii, 321 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Victorinus (AD 269-271). In one of the bottles were also found a pendant medallion (with a denarius of Antoninus Pius) and a silver finger ring.
disposition: Service Régional de l’Archéologie, Ile-de- Franceté; Centre Michel de Boüard – Centre de recherches archéologiques et historiques anciennes et médiévales, Caen

summary: 50 radiates, mainly of the Gallic Empire and terminating with Carausius, found near Conwy shortly after 1945. No more specific information on the find spot is available.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver weight: 54.9-502.2+
512 provincial bronze coins were found in a ceramic vessel. 480 coins are kept in the museum of Sevlievo: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: History Museum, Sevlievo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 263

summary: 11 antoniniani (radiates) found with a small ceramic vessel in a well: Gordian III - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). The hoard was found together with a brooch and/or a Gold ring (according to Dembski).
146 coins: 1 denarius, 91 antoniniani (radiates), 49 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 3 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal stone font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal bone, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a stone cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins
2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2765.1-5725.2g
8 provincial bronze coins issued under Gordian III by Edessa (6 coins) and either Edessa or Carrhae (2 coins).

The hoard originally comprised 50.591 antoniniani: Gordianus III - Maximian I ( AD 293). Almost the whole hoard was acquired and now 45.873 coins are kept in the Museo di Castelvecchio, Verona. This find is extensively published. 168 kilos.
disposition: Verona, Museo di Castelvecchio, 45873 coins; otherwise dispersed

summary: Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. Two dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.
1,486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.
87 bronze coins: 2 imperial, 85 provincial: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. 3635 (87 coins)

summary: 3rd century. Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between two occupation layers/phases of use contained a 'large quantitity of objects' incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.

Unknown initial number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 240 pieces entered the museum collection in Dalgopol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249). Mints: Marcianopolis, Mesembria, Tomis.
Hoard of 2,093 coins of the Bosporan kings, Ininthimeus and Rhescuporis V (AD 242-276).
61 silver coins found in a Roman villa: 22 denarii, 39 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 100.8-168.5 g.
The hoard comprised 43 sestertii from Commodus to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
16 holed antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Valerian I and Gallienus to Quintillus (AD 270).
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The find consists of 10 late Roman bronze coins (Tetricus, and other Gallic emperors), found in the area of the 'Kulturhaus am Hexenturm'
52 coins: 51 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 269). 1 Denarius.
642 BI radiates to AD 282. Addenda of 100 coins found in 2015.
Group of six coins: aureus of Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I), aureus of Postumus and 4 denarii of Augustus found in grave no. 8.
IARCH record for a small hoard of 10 radiates. Possibly associated with the Chalgrove II hoard (IARCH-CB9058) but recorded separately due to uncertainty over this association.

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 600 coins, apparently antoniniani (radiates). A further 9 coins were recovered from the bed of a small stream that ran into the pond. These coins were of the same emperors as those contained in the hoard.
The hoard comprised 2,118 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Aurelian with a tpq of AD 270 to 275.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1991-214/1 - jug; 2:1 - 2120

summary: The hoard was characterised as a 'cachette'. It comprised approximately 350 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Aurelian and other emperors of the period. The coins were generally well-preserved.
167 silver coins: 97 denarii, 70 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Diocletian (AD 295).
disposition: formerly Regional museum Tiel (destroyed during WWII)

summary: A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a fifteenth century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver weight: 31.5-140.3g.
The hoard comprised 2,432 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 256. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 3513.1-7304.9g
The hoard comprised fragments of a greyware vessel containing 90 sestertii from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 261.

33 Alexandrian tetradrachms and a fragment of a bronze-ring. Found in a wooden jar in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293).
The hoard comprised 21 denarii from Vitellius to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 201 to 206. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 39.6-60.8 g.
Three aurei part of a chain, 2 mounted in pendants: Valerian I (2), Valerianus II Caesar) (AD 255-256)

7 coins: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii; 1 medallion of bronze and gold and silver jewelry were found within a child grave: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
A bunch of 12 antoniniani: Claudius II - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard was recovered from the site of a Gallo-Roman vicus during illegal excavations and comprised a denarius of Septimius Severus and 561 sestertii from Vespasian to Septimius Severus (ad 193-211).
Unknown initial number of coins. 11 silver coins in the Museum of Ruse: 1 denarius, 10 antoniniani: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 16.2 g.
disposition: History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1495 (initially, 12 coins, after robbery only 8)

summary: The hoard comprised 16 sestertii from Hadrian to Philip I and 25 denarii and radiates from Caracalla to Valerian I (AD 253-260).

A group of 14 Roman provincial bronzes of Pontic cities (Zela, Amasia, Comana, Sebastopolis), now in the Ankara museum, and judging from its composition, probably found nearby Zela. All coins were minted in the year 205/206, under Septimius Severus.
(+200) sestertii: Septimius Severus 2, Severus Alexander 12: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235)
Unknown initial number of coins. Based on the diameter it is assumed they were sestertii. 51 coins were examined: Hadrian - Postumus (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 16 sestertii: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 240) minted in Rome and a further one from the mint in Viminacium (Trajan Decius, AD 251).

(1200) 290 denarii: Otho - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235). Found together with: 1 gold torque of twisted wire, 2 silver torques, 2 silver bracelets, 10 silver appliques, 1 silver brooch, 1 silver ring with inscription.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXXXIX (1934)

summary: Unknown quantity of provincial bronze coins. 2 pieces of Caracalla minted in Serdica are known
615 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 185.4-767.8g.
Hoard of 1,500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) found in several amphoras: Clodius Albinus - Gallienus (AD 260-268). Found together with a gold chain.
(c. 7-8000) 5103 silver coins: 3 denarii, 5100 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Tetrarchy (AD 294)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium; Archaeological Museum, Arlon, Belgium

summary: The hoard comprised about 600 bronzes of Postumus.
Hoard of 228 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic pitcher. 225 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270); silver weight: 61.5-279.0 g.
disposition: Direzione generale per le Antichità e le Belle Arti, Torino, Italy (in 1904).

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 189 silver and copper-alloy coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - from Antoninus Pius to Gallienus.
A hoard of 45 antoniniani found in the burial of a soldier killed during the siege for Dura Europos in 256/7.
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Hadrianopolis found in the dirt when digging a sewer: Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 618, 624, 628, 632, 635, 639, 642, 645, 648, 654, 657, 684, 694

summary: A Roman hoard was found and dispersed, in recent years in Nembro. Some bronze coins of the 3rd century were seen. It is an Antoninianus (radiate) from Salamina (sic!) and dupondii of Claudius II and Aurelian (determination of E. Arslan). Soprintendenza Archeologica della Lombardia (7 coins).

Around 550 antoniniani (including an antoninianus of Pacatianus) were found by metal detecting. The coins were placed in a ceramic vessel and another ceramic vessel serving as a lid. The coins were sold without documentation. Ten coins came into possesion of H. Nowak: Valerian I 5, Gallienus 3, Salonina 1, Valerian II 1 (AD255-258).
The hoard comprised 22 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Gallienus and Claudius II (AD 268-270).
A small set of coins that were glued together to form a small cylinder were found next to a corpse.
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver weight: 1463.8-3029.0 g.
67 antoniniani (radiates): 57 Gallienus (sole), 10 Salonina (AD 260-268).
disposition: Civiche Raccolte Numismatiche di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M 999.08.1-M 999.08.67)

summary: 142 bronze coins (sestertii, antoniniani?): Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); silver weight: 27.9-59.7g.
22 coins were reported on, although it is likely that there were originally a few more (although not many more) in the hoard. Metcalfe suggests that there were originally 26 coins.
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 50 coins are kept in the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22 092-22 141 (50 coins)

summary: A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver weight: 71.8-592.1
(300) 194 Ant: Gordian III - Valerianus I or Gallienus (sole reign ?) Gordian III 52
27 sestertii found together in a room from a Roman building considered to shave served as a warehouse.

A hoard 437 coins (?), composed of 1 denarius (Maximinus) and 436 antoniniani (325: Julia Domna - Gallienus; 111: Gallic empire) to AD 263, found in excavations conducted by the curé M. Duchâtel in Noyers. Note that the catalogue only lists 324 antonininiani for the period Julia Domna - Gallienus and 109 for the Gallic Empire (i.e. 434 coins in total, and not 437).
Unknown Initial number of coins. 16 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 11 provincial: Nero - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 410 bronze coins. Desjobert gave a description of four sestertii from the hoard which were in the Abbot Gilbert and Abbot Lottin Collections. Legeay noted that the emperors Augustus, Vespasian, Marcus Aurelius, Antoninus Pius and Postumus. This information was not repeated by Leadru.

The hoard comprised 'a bucketful of Roman coins, fused together with corrosion products. Cochet estimated that the total number of coins in the hoard was more than 300. The coins were antoniniani (radiates) of the third century depicting 10 emperors until Tacitus and Probus.
disposition: Musées d’Angers, France; Accession Register III, p. 37, no. 42 (3.11.1876)

summary: Around 5,000 antoniniani (radiates), 13.5 kg. The majority of coins belonged to Tetricus I and Tetricus II. Other issuers: Gallienus, Salonina, Victorinus, Postumus, Marius, Cludius II, Quintillus, Quintillus (Divus Cludius II), Aurelian.
During archaeological excavations, 11 burned bronze coins were found on the south-east corner of the basilica: 1 Rome, 10 provincial: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
359 billon coins. Acquired by J.P. Six together with another two (?) hoards, consisting in Ptolemaic bronze coins and 178 Roman folles respectively.

The hoard comprised a large earthenware vessel containing 1,100 bronze coins (for the most part sestertii) and 30 'small coins with surface silvering' (radiates). A summary catalogue of 200 of the best preserved examples was made by F. Homo. The hoard was found by workmen from the Letellier company during quarrying for stone. It was found at only a slight depth 'faible profondeur'.
Unknown number of antoniani were found in unknown circumstances. 6 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Trebonianus Gallus 1, Valerian I 2, Gallienus 2, Claudius ?? 1.

The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.

520 imperial and provincial bronze coins: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249). The bulk of the coins consists in issues of Marcianopolis (249+ ex.), followed by coins from Odessus, Tomis, Anchialus, Mesembria, Dionysopolis and Bizya.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (450 coins)

summary: Hoard of 44 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-252).
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
11 provincial bronze coins minted in Deultum: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv. no. ?XXV

summary: The hoard was found in the northeast part of the Roman fort during an excavation campaign in 1983. It comprised 4 aurei and 70 denarii, ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.

The hoard comprised 64 'bronze' coins from Caracalla to Gallienus. The denominational composition of the hoard is not given. It was found in the South Stoa. In front of shop XX was a strosis covered with a thick layer of burned debris. In this charred stratum, within the storeroom, were found the iron fittings of a money box containing the hoard.
3 coins: 1 denarius Antoninus Pius, 2 aurei Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Collection de Pitteurs, Budingen, Belgium, in 1850

summary: At least 1,772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.
(150) 102 bronze coins: 1 imperial, 149 provincial coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 866 (102 coins)

summary: 10 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III 4, Philip I 5, Trebonianus Gallus (Volusianus Augustus) 1 (AD 251-253). Weight coins: 35.74 g. Found together with two silver bracelets and two Anchor type silver brooches and one bronze ring. Weight jewelry: 186.83 g.
32 antoniniani ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
3 kilograms of coins. 154 entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Gordian III - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 28.3-191.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1118-1133

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 81 antoniniani (radiates) are available: Trebonianus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 18.5-80.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria; inv.no. XVII, XXXIV; History Museum, Sliven, Bulgaria (3 coins); History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1066 /0-12/

summary: 3,510 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius: Philip I - Aurelianus (AD 270-275)
