67 antoniniani discovered in a room with hypocaust of a Roman edifice: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

A hoard of 265 provincial bronze coins (of which 202 were identifiable), found at Dura Europos in a room of the Roman barracks (like hoard 15, though nothing indicated that these were part of the same hoard).). Many of the coins were badly preserved. 63 illegible coins were are not listed in Bellinger's Final report.
(147) 142 bronze coins: 1 as, 141 provincial: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 22

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 516 sestertii from Titus to Gordian III. There is a discrepancy regarding the total number of coins found. The total given varies between 550 and 600 coins, of which only 515 sestertii and 1 dupondius or as of Sabina survive.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico de Ibiza y Formentera, Spain

summary: According to the catalogue prepared by P. Fustier, the hoard comprised 280 denarii and 847 antoniniani (radiates). However, this total must be considered as approximate as Fustier identified numerous coins as being radiates of Plautilla, a combination that does not exist. The hoard was found by a quarry worker called Rodriquez. It was almost completely dispersed although the Musée de Roanne did acquire 4 denarii of Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla and Plautilla. Silver weight: 2064.9-4044.9g.
The hoard comprised 114 sestertii: Trajan-Gordian III (98-243 AD).

HER record of a hoard of 102 coins found in the river at Thornborough. Appears to be a hoard dislodged from the river bank rather than an accumulation of finds deposited in the river. Latest coin Carausius or Diocletian.

Coins run from Mark Antony to Trajan Decius, although it has been argued that the last coins could be intrusive. In that case, the hoard would end with issues of Gordian III. 81,096 (and not 81,044!) coins were published in 1934 by Mouchmov, after a further 20,000+ coins had been dispersed. The total number of coins therefore exceeds 101,096 specimens. The difference between our comput and the 81,044 coins mentioned in the original publication resides in an error in counting the number of coins of Commodus (3146, whereas 3191 is correct) and reporting the correct number of coins of Caracalla in the table p. 6 of Mouchmov's publication. Note that further errors have occurred for Trajan (p. 21, last three entries, where numbers do not add up).
disposition: National Museum, Sofia (ca. 68,783 coins). Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria: inv.nos. 2807-2829, 4301-16363 (12,261 coins: Nero - Gordian III)

summary: Concentration of 12 denarii and one drachm of Amisus (Hadrian), found in two adjacent excavations (1988/03 and 1992/42). This could well be a scattered purse or hoard.

Unknown initial number of coins. 15 bronze and billon coins entered the collection of the museum in Cagliari: 7 sestertii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 4.6-19.5g.

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised a ceramic pot containing approximately '400 middle and small bronzes dating to the third century AD': Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

Small hoard of 15 ant. of Gallienus to Tetricus II, from 'Dover General Deposits', reported on by Peter Curnow & Richard Reece, all show evidence of wear, majority clipped.Reece, R. 2012. The Roman coins. In B. Philp The Discovery and Excavation of the Roman Shore-fort at Dover, Kent. Kent Archaeological Monographs 11. Kent Archaeol. Rescue Unit, pp. 108.

The hoard was found as the result of deep-ploughing which brought 126 small Roman bronzes to the surface which were collected by farmers. An archaeological excavation then revealed a greyware vessel filled with more radiates and a further pink ceramic vessel containing 1,276 coins. Two containers, one with 988 antoniniani (radiates) from Julia Domna to Postumus, the other 1,437 from Valerian to Tetricus II Silver: 2,425 coins; silver weight: 730.8-3581.8g.
43 silver and bronze coins, plated denarii: 41 denarii (19 plated), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 228-231). Found in the Principia building of the 5th Macedonica Legion fort.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.
The hoard comprised a small casket or box containing silver and copper-alloy coins from Vespasian, Antoninus Pius and Trebonianus Gallus.
487 silver coins: 227 denarii, 260 antoniniani (radiates): Balbinus - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further details.
7 antoniniani (4 copies) Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (11 coins); collection Vandermaelen (2 coins and the shards from vessel), in 1851

summary: A hoard of 10 antoniniani (Valerian I - Gallienus) found in a destruction deposit of a Roman villa 500 metres from Chaeronea.
The hoard comprised 71 silver coins and 85 bronze coins from a Roman shipwreck.
Few hundreds silver coins. 467 silver coins were reovered: Nero – Elagabalus (AD 218-222). No further details.
disposition: Bruckenthal Museum, Sibiu (420 coins); National History Museum, Bucharest (47 coins)

summary: 32 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
(c. 1400) 1352 antoniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268); silver weight: c.1751.4-3638.7 g.
disposition: Museum Dauphinoise, Grenoble, France; part of the coins and the container.

summary: The hoard comprised 'an earthenware vessel filled with 652 silver and billon coins (denarii and radiates) and 100 bronzes (sestertii and dupondii or asses). The silver and billon coins weighed 3.7kg. A further 186 coins were offered for sale in Rouen in 1971 and appear to be from the same hoard.' The coins were deposited at the Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen, where 168 examples were actually conserved and catalogued by Mme J. Delaporte. Archives Inventory No. 2-653.
disposition: Bibliothèque municipale de Rouen (Archives Inventory No. 2-653)

summary: 42 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 12 have been examined: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
357 silver coins: 154 denarii, 203 antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip (AD 244-247); silver weight: 470.8-965.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised approximately 300 radiates of which 64 survive.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing 550 3rd century ADcoins including issues of Gordian III and Philip I.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons

Unnown number of Roman coins found duing the construction clay station. Among them: Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius dupondius, Marcus Aurelius sestertius, Gordian III dupondius, Philip I (Otacilia Severa) sestertius, Gallienus (Salonina) antoninianus (radiate).
44 silver coins: 16 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 243-244); Silver weight: 57.8-100.7g
1,545 coins: 1 denarius, 1544 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Tetricus I (AD 271-273).

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.
A big vessel full of Roman imperial coins, bronzes and antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius - Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
128 silver coins (antoniniani?): Balbinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
1,401 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
A hoard of 11 antoniniani (Valerian I to Postumus) was found in the Schwemmerstraße.
Six sestertii: Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander 2, Julia Mammea, Maximinus I Thrax, Paulin (Diva) brought together with other Roman materials: glass urns, bricks.
122 antoniniani (radiates) found near the reservoir tank of the Roman villa: Valerian I and Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
disposition: Laboratório de Conservação e Restauro (Direcção Regional da Cultura do Alentejo), Portugal

summary: 15 provincial bronzes found during the salvage excavation at Zeugma in 1998, on the floor of a house. The report in Coin Hoards mentions '15 AE of Zeugma in the names of Gordian III, Philip I and Philip II'. However, there are no coins of Zeugma issued under Gordian III, so these must belong to a different mint.

In 1951, 119 Roman bronze coins of Claudius II, Tetricus I and II were found under a heavy slab of stone while clearing wasteland. Almost all are imitations, possibly produced nearby as most are also mint fresh.
30 antoninianii, ranging from Gordian III to Volusian, were unearthed at the Roman fort Biriciana, on the via principalis near the porta dextra during excavations in 1892.
Gold and silver coins found together with tableware, two gold bracelets and rings in a lead chest. At least two aurei of Philip and Gallienus. Gold: 2+ coins; Gold weight: 10.2g+;
Circa 2,000 coins, only 3 known: 2 of Severus Alexander, 1 of Philip I

The hoard comprised 53 Roman bronze coins (sestertii?) from Galba to Elagabalus. A coin of Maximian I was also found but this is thought to have been a stray loss, rather than being part of the hoard.
Initial quantity of silver coins: 13 kg, Studied: 9 kg (Gerov, B.) = 1790 coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 2238.1-4652.9 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 843-856 (1716 coins, stolen 1407)

summary: While digging for the foundations of a house a ceramic vessel with some tens silver coins was found. 63 pieces were examined: 6 antoniniani, 57 denarii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

During groundwork a coin hoard of 310 coins was unearthed near the Roman fort of Gunzenhausen. It comprised 308 denarii and 2 antoninianii, ranging from Commodus to Gordian III. Note that FMRD lists 310 coins, but in the summary only gives 309.
The hoard comprised an iron vessel containing between 700 and 800 coins of Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).

29 Roman silver coins found at Chew Stoke, ranging from Republican denarii to the 3rd century AD. This may be the hoard mentioned by Rahtz (1957, 114) as having been found on Pagan's Hill by its then owner Mr Gray in 1870, though 40-50 silver coins were found. Very wide date spread, which may indicate a shrine or temple in use for a long time rather than a specific hoard (EG).
The hoard contains in total 18 coins. 1 antoninianus, 17 denarii. Coins of Septimius Severus, Julia Mamea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I (AD 244-246).
8 coins of Tetricus I, including some imitations, located in the museum of Bad Dürkheim and allegedly found 1854 in an urn. This could be a hoard, or part of one, or a grave find.

The hoard comprised approximately 400 coins (although Ledru states the total was more than 1400 coins - an error?). Hucher compiled an inventory of 260 sestertii which were bought by the Musée du Mans Found in a field on the Villeneuve farm. Hollard gives a total number of 280 coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique du Mans, France (1892) - 260 coins

summary: 24 silver coins: 3 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Caracalla - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2372

summary: 475 silver coins: 1 Celtic drahm, 1 provincial drachm, 3 republican denarii, 470 imperial, found in the river near the former Postumius Bridge pillar. It was presumed that the coins may have been kept in a chest/box: Celtic - Gordian III (AD 240).
disposition: Musei Civici di Castelvecchio di Verona, Italy

summary: 45 silver coins: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
NA
Hoard of initial of just over 100 aurei, 91 recovered (650 g = two Roman pounds): Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 231).
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Madrid (at the moment); Provincial Archaeological Museum of Cáceres, Spain (final destination)

summary: The hoard comprised silver denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 254.
Unknown number of coins. 63 antoniniani were seen: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
Few hundreds, only 16 (8 imitations) antoniniani (radiates) known Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Philip I.

The hoard was found in two ceramic vessels hidden under some large stones. It comprised more than 8,500 bronze coins of which 7,978 (Hucher) or 8,117 (Lallemand) radiates and copies were identified. Callu estimated that 5.2% of the coins were imitations. The hoard was found during stone quarrying under some large stones: Philip I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver weight: 1517.4-14518.3
Unknown original number of coins. Only one of 25+ coins has been recorded and is known. All the coins are likely to have been denarii or antoniniani (radiates).
1,173 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 317.7-1465.3g.
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: Within lumps, the coins were arranged in stacks shifted sideways, 389 silver coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates). All coins were covered with a light green patina. There are 88 denarii: Clodius Albius to Gordian III and 301 antoniniani (radiates): Macrinus Valerian I and Gallienus).
Circa 585 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 176.4-730.3g.
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver weight: 584.0-1024.5 g.
Forty-sevenound with a ceramic vessel. 45 coins provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna) (AD 211-217).
980 antoniniani (radiates) found in two lots, in 1962, 1980, in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 272).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Bibliotheque Nationale de France, Paris

summary: The hoard comprised 'several hundred small bronze coins'. Canel distinguishes this hoard from those found in Préaux (TAF IV. 57). The hoard was near the top of the hill, close to the plough, approximately 1km from the ancient abbey of Saint-Léger.
The hoard comprised 24 antoniniani: Gallienus (sole)-Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270 AD).
disposition: Museo Civico Bottacin di Padova, Italy (inv.nos. 24174-24196)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic jar containing 37 bronze and silver coins dated between 146-139 BC and AD 193-211. The hoard was found in association with the remains of an ancient building, but this was destroyed during construction work.

A hoard of ca. 150 Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Septimius Severus), found in Winnefeld while planting trees. 133 coins were acquired by the museum in Hannover, 117 of which can still be traced. Several coins are badly preserved and identifications are tentative.
1943 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: 1942 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Antoninus Pius - MAximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
(500-600) 142 denarii: Vespasian - Balbinus (AD 238); silver weight: 771.6-1621.0 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coin); collection L. Renard-Grenson (113 coins), Liège, Belgium; private collection (22 coins).

summary: Unknown initial number of denarii. 10 known: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 58.2-107.9 g.

1,051 radiates of the later third century (Valerian to Tetricus I) found at a quarry. According to Lee (1862), the coins were in a "covered pot or pan of common black ware which was unfortunately broken."
Unknown number of antoniniani. 3,562 coins in the Regional History Museum of Vidin: Gordian III - Aurelian (AD270-275).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1074

summary: 74 coins found with a Roman bronze jug: Vespasian - Valerian I (AD 256-257). Together were found: an Almgren 157 fibula, five bracelets, a pendant and two silver ingots on silver. The discovery has been interpreted as a silver craftsman hoard.
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, ploiești, Romania (inv.nos. 72696-72766)

summary: 404 silver coins: Commodus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1483

summary: 41 silver hoards: 2 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus (Julia Maesa) - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 260-268). The coins were found together in a small pit.
8 coins: 6 antoniniani (radiates), 1 sestertius, 1 as: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Postumus (AD 260-269).

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: 246 denarii found while ploughing: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 202)
250 coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 247 sestertii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 213-217); silver weight: 7.4-8.5 g.
The hoard comprises 1,931 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Philip I, as well as a single drachm of Geta from Caesarea in Cappadocia. Found with a ceramic vessel.
2,191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver weight: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

summary: 341 denarii (86 information lost) found before 2000; 31 denarii found in 2013. Hadrian - Septimius Severus (AD 201).
disposition: Historisch Museum Deventer; De Nederlandsche Bank (Dutch National Central Bank)

summary: The hoard comprised 27 coins from Gallienus to Postumus and Tetricus I and one gold ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 8.7 and 31.5 g.

29 3rd-century coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I & II. Scattered along the bottom of an internal drain in building 2170. Dated by the excavators to AD 290, presumably on the basis of the barbarous radiate, though this could be earlier (listed as "reverse Pax" by Reece in Woodward et al. 116).Woodward et al. 1993. Excavations at Greyhound Yard, Dorchester 1981-4. DNHAS Mono. 12, pp. 62, 82, 116, figs 23, 30, plate 30. Building 2170

The hoard comprised 606 radiates from Balbinus to Postumus with a tpq of approximately AD 263. The hoard contains official issues up until Postumus' Issue 1c (AD 261) but there are two radiates which copy coins of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 141.2 and 1222.6g.

The hoard was found in two boxes next to a lead coffin in a Gallo-Roman cemetery. The boxes contained masses of radiates and included amongst them, issues of Postumus and Tetricus I. Found in a sandpit.
A hoard of 428 denarii dating from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (235/236) and one Caesarean drachm of Septimius Severus found at Sulakyurt.
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara, Turkez

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Varna: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 4328-4372 (45 coins)

summary: In 1897 a hoard of silver coins was discovered a little south of the Ladenburg/Keplerstraße junction. Only half of the coins are known, because the others were sold to America. The list given here includes a Greek coin, and 129 denarii and antoninini (late Republic to Postumus).
The hoard comprised 14 radiates from AD 253 to AD 259.
20 antoniniani. No further information .
During the construction of a spinning factory in 1852 a hoard consisting of gold and silver coins, ranging from Nero to Severus Alexander, was unearthed. Only 27 specimens were documented.

A hoard of 46 mostly bronze coins (26 provincial and 20 imperial), ranging from Domitian to Trajan Decius, found scattered on the floor of Villa A, in a destruction layer associated with the Sassanid invasion.
33 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelianus (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy

summary: The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 'containing 9kg coins, mostly 3rd century small bronzes of the Gallic emperors, Gallienus, Postumus etc., although according to Triger there were some earlier coins of Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, and Justine (sic). This information was repeated by numismatic reviews and by Blanchet. In 1911, Ledru wrote about the coins acquired by Julien and Louis Chappée and gave a list of emperors. A lot of 1,219 coins were bought by the Musée du Mans in 1890. The hoard was found during quarrying. Silver weight: c.812.3-7797.7g.
A large number of denarii and antoniniani was found in a ceramic vessel. 520 denarii are kept in the museum of Ruse: Vitellius - Gordian III (AD 242-243).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1705

summary: 18 antoniniani (raddiates) found in the dump of the ancient quarry: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Around 500 radiates (Valerian I to Diocletian) found by a workman in a rock crevice inside a coal mine near Aberkenfig. The coins were apparently lying on a fragment of decayed cloth, suggesting a container. Three different lists of this hoard exist, totalling c. 530, 500 and 492 coins. The list here follows the one given by Robertson, based on the 492 coins deposited at the National Museum Cardiff.
The hoard comprised one or two vessels filled with silver and billon coinage of different sizes of which one was of Gallienus and one Postumus'
42 aurei: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258); Gold weight: 237.9 g.

The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel covered with a copper-alloy plate and comprised approximately 10,000 radiates of Tetricus I, Victorinus, Gallienus, Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus and Probus. Only 18 coins were preserved.
An uncertain number of coins. Only two denarii of Caracalla were identified.

The hoard comprised 801 sestertii from Vespasian or Titus to Maximinus I Thrax with a tpq of AD 236. Although no trace of a container was recovered, the coins were found stacked, as if they had been stored in rolls in a box.
The hoard comprised more than 1,500 Roman coins. The Museé de Boulogne bought 100 coins ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus.
Unknown initial number number of coins. T. Gerasimov mentions 12 silver coins: 3 denarii, 9 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Found in a ceramic vessel

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 1,500 and 2,000 third century bronzes. 105 of these coins were identified. All were radiates, although it was noted that originally there were a 'certain number' of denarii of Postumus. 100 coins from the hoard were acquired by the Musée de Poitiers. Silver: c.1500-2000 (105) coins; Silver weight: 473.5-2186.5
disposition: Museum of Poitiers; private collections (2 coins); some coins lost

summary: Between 25,000-30,000 coins found in two bronze vessels: 8 or 10 aurei from Hadrian to Severus Alexander; 5 bronze coins (Septimius Severus, Severus Alexander, Philip II, Postumus); 1 bronze medallion of Severus Alexander (with Julia Mamaea); 25,000-30,000 silver and billon coins from Claudius (I/II?) to Postumus; gold weight: c. 64.8 g; Silver: c.25-30,000 coins; Silver weight: c.7427.6-71498.9. Together were found jewelry: 30 gold and silver rings; two or three pairs of gold earrings; a pair of bracelets, two styla, 30 silver spoons; a gold necklace (?).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing one silver coin and an unknown number of copper-alloy coins of Marcus Aurelius, Commodus and Julia Mamaea.
Of those seen (934), were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Sverus to Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1364.0-1708.8g.
676 Roman imperial bronzes found in the ground: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
4 bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235). Found together with an iron scale, a bronze weigh and scale pan fragments. Most likely ot a set for weighing.
All are imitations: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 116.4-203.9g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg

summary: The hoard comprised 1 Hellenistic coin of Thessalonica, 1 plated denarius of Septimius Severus and 28 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella and Stobi, Augustus - Gordian III). It was brought from Macedonia by a soldier who had found them while digging trenches.
22 Syrian tetradrachms, ranging from Elagabalus to Trebonianus Gallus, found in destruction deposits of Room 9J.

The hoard comprised more than 30 'large bronze Roman coins. TAF speculates as to whether it is an entire hoard or part of a larger hoard. Found in a gravel quarry.32 coins were donated to the museum by M. Caille: Trajan - Postumus (AD 260-69).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen, France. Inventory: III, 2, p. 78, no. 2005 (5.11.1908).

summary: The hoard comprised 13 bronze coins, dated between AD 244-253.
90 silver coins: 36 denarii, 54 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius - Valerian I (AD 257); silver weight: 114.7-196.4 g.
Unknown quantity of coins. 3,693 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv. No further information.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2644; 3,693 coins

summary: Ceramic vessel containing 610 Roman provincial bronze coins: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 235-238). Minted mostly in Tomis (today, Constanța, Romania). Other mint, identified so far, Deultum; At the bottom of container, iron carpentry tools: penknife, clamping clamp, ax/chisel, wood gripper, bolt.
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie din Constanţa

summary: 1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.

Unknown initial number of coins. Five coins are known: 1 Greek coin, 3 denarii, 2 plated denarii: 2nd c. BC - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205). It may be a votive offering as suggested by some scholars based on the findspot.
5,056 silver coins found in one or more ceramic vessels: 17 denarii, 5,039 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 966.5g.
103 coins, range: Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus. No further details.
357 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius, ranging from Caracalla to Aemilian (AD 253); silver weight: 448.5-804.5 g.
disposition: Archives de la Commission d'assistance publique (358 coins); private collection (3 coins); Musée communal de Bruxelles"

summary: A hoard of at least 121 denarii and antoniniani (Septimius Severus - Valerian I), found by two metal detectors in 2006. Some coins were preserved in fragmentary form and these fragments could account for another 1-3 specimens.
The hoard was found in an amphora and comprised 63 coins of Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).

Four aurei and jewelrey: Trajan Decius - Gallienus (sole) found with a copper vessel. Some of the objects were taken by the finder. According to the finder, Near the vessel was a stone in a vertical position.
disposition: Institut d'Archéologie de Bucarest; Musée National d'Histoire de Bucarest; dispersed

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. Dr. Haralanov examined 468 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Two provincial coins, minted in Alexandria (Diocletian and Maximian), found on a field in ca. 1900.
The hoard was found in a stone conduit at a mineral water source and comprised 67 Roman bronze and billon coins from Claudius I to Tetricus I.
25 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Maximianus I (AD 285-286); silver weight: 4.6-6.8g.
32 silver coins discovered in a small ceramic vessel: 7 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2574

summary: 416 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gordian III - Carus (AD 282-283) found in the courtyard, having been stored in an amphora and placed in a bin, during excavations of a house.

The hoard comprised a plain ceramic vessel containing 628 Roman coins from Trajan Decius to Tetricus I. These included 3 denarii of Postumus and 625 silver, billon or bronze coins (denarii and radiates) of several emperors. The coins of Claudius II and the Tetrici constituted 5/6ths of the hoard.
39 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-256). Purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".
disposition: 'Selection in Oxford, where there is also a handwritten list (Milne); some of the rest are probably in Toronto'

summary: (160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver weight: 181.8-353.2 g.
The hoard comprised close to 20,000 coins of which 490 were seen. These included issues of Saloninus, Gallienus and Postumus.
It comprised 3,000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.

In 1983/4 a hoard of silver coins (denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Vespasian to Gallienus, joint reign) was found scattered in a field, in the German-Dutch border area, close to Aachen-Richterich, on the site of a villa rustica. The hoard was dispersed. The total number of coins was estimated at more than 650 specimens. Some coins were sold, some others are now in the Rheinisches Landesmuseum, Bonn. FMRD lists 747 coins.
Unknown number of bronze coins. 90 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2145-2230

summary: 54 antoniniani (radiates) found near a wall of a building (Principia?) from the legionary fortress: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
A hoard of 260 provincial bronze coins (Domitian - Gallus, including one from the First Jewish Revolt), found at Dura Europos, in L8 W102, the street along the wall near the main Gate.
The hoard was placed next to the skull of a skeleton in an inhumation grave and comprised 33 small bronzes antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

A set of 206 coins (Claudius II - Gallic Empire), dug out during dredging work in the Mosel river, ca.100m below the Kaiser Wilhelm bridge on the western edge of the narrow island. The coins were soldered together in a clump. The 8 coins listed under ID 16853 (FMRD 3011,3) belong probably to the sam find.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
15 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 20

summary: Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).
59+ antoniniani ranging of Aurelian and Probus.
A hoard of 866 denarii, ranging from Mark Antony to Elagabalus, and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia, found during blasting at a quarry near Obererbach in 1944.
4,116 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 bronzes: Greek - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 284-295). Acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
disposition: 185 were sent to Macalister. The rest is partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford (Milne)

summary: 18 silver coins entered the museum collection in Nova Zagora: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1159

summary: On the basis of their condition and inventory numbers the coins perhaps also belong to the complex of the Keplerstraße hoard, see CHRE ID 3713.
ca. 40 coins in a leather purse, but only 5 coins are identified: Septimius Severus (1), Postumus (4).
The hoard comprises 127 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a top of AD 250-251.
Unknown initial umber of coins. 46 denarii: Vespasian - Elagabalus (AD 222).
749 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Carinus (AD 284).

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).
12,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
14 coins found in a grave: 1 denarius, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Caracalla) - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

The hoard was found in the ruins of a small round temple and comprised a tripod cauldron containing 251 Roman sestertii from Domitian to Gordian III. Coins of Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus were the most numerous.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii from Vespasian to Commodus, 1 dupondius of Caracalla and 281 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 351.8g to 729.5g
102 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian and Diocletian (AD 286-287) found in a pile at floor level (along the wall of a room) during excavations of a house.
Unknown number of denarii. 199 entered the museum collection in Silistra: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 217).
Unknown initial number of coins. 69 bronze coins: Augustus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,020 coins; 9 aurei Vespasian to Plautilla. Gold: 9 coins; Gold weight: 64.0-64.7g; Silver: 1011 coins; Silver weight: 1851.2-2920.7g

A hoard of 500 silver coins (Mark Antony - Caracalla) found in a beaker on a new housing site, to be known as Clarney Place. The find was made 400 yards from the Darfield 1947 (Darfield I) hoard, but their depositions do not seem to be related. Carson and Corder published the hoard in 1948, but the catalogue does not align exactly to the coin summary. Trajan, Hadrian, Septimius Severus and Caracalla all have one fewer specimens in the catalogue compared to the summary, while the reverse is true for Otho. Since it is agreed that the hoard numbered 500, the summary has been regarded as the correct description of the hoard's contents.

A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated one) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO C)
summary: Hoard in grave, 9 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
45 silver coins: 3 denarii, 42 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 57.1-113.3 g

The hoard comprises 182 antoniniani (radiates). The 182 pieces were found stacked on three rows: in the first two there were series of 13 to 15 coins forming tubes on the edges above the lowest series. At the lower level they appeared more arbitrarily placed in a larger radius. Three tegulae formed a vault over the whole.

The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full extent is unknown. FMRD gives three lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 3062,2) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 3062,3) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 3062,4) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 3062,5)
45 silver coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 63.1-128.9 g.

One drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Julia Domna) and 78 antoniniani (radiates) (Julia Maesa to Gallienus), found in the northwest-west suburb of Kerch. 71 of these were published by N. Kunina in 1962. To these, Golenko adds a further 8 antoniniani.
(+200) 126 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 38.8-156.5 g.
(?) 112 silver coins: 17 denarii, 95 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258); silver weight: c. 875.6-1818.9 g
disposition: Town Museum Marienmont, Morlanwelz-Marienmont, Belgium (109 coins)

summary: A hoard of 751 AE radiates, & 1 AE denarius and pottery to AD 286 in a black burnished ware jar. Unpublished coin report by R. Abdy.
2,290 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: Commodus - Valerian I (AD 257-259).
505 antoniniani (radiates), of which 358 are catalogued: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (AD 290).
disposition: Castello del Buonconsiglio di Trento, Italy (358 coins); Museo di Riva, Italy (126 coins, stolen)

summary: 12 coins found together in a pit that served as a cellar to an agricultural building. Probably were kept in a leather or fabric purse: 1 bronze medallion, 7 sestertii, 4 dupondii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 240).
199 Roman imperial large bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).Possible part of the same hoard as Capoterra 1928a.
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). 352 coins were recovered: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: From 57 coins found on the excavated area, according to B. Prokisch 24 coins may have been part of a hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-259). A gold bracelet was found with these coins.
The hoard comprised 335 antoniniani (radiates) dating between the reigns of Valerian and Claudius II.
disposition: Dispersed in trade. Recorded at the British Museum.

summary: Funerary find. 'A large number of coins finds' between large Stone blocks. Near the place were found human bones and funerary inventory. The 30 coins analyzed revealed antoniani of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus and Claudius II (AD 268-270). No further Information.
disposition: Society of Natural History Savoie (30 coins)

summary: The hoard was found in a large iron pot and comprised approximately 29 kilos (close to 120 marcs) of Roman silver coins. The coins were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from the reign of Septimius Severus to Gallienus and Postumus. Cochet suggested purely hypothetically that this hoard was found in Saint-André-Sur-Cailly.

In a cavern, without precise location, found during blast operations. Ca. 80 coins, mainly from the 3rd c. AD: Postumus (Gallic Empire, 260–269), Gallienus (253–268), Salonina (wife of Gallienus), Claudius II (268–270), Victorinus (269–270) and Aurelian (270–275) among other emperors of the 3rd c. AD. Later reports mention coins of Trajan, Decius (= Trajan Decius?) and Diocletian. Only two coins are preserved. There were more coin finds reported from the same region, Mollis-Bodenwald, in the 1820's and ca. 1831, but no coins are preserved (cf. Diaz Tabernero et al., Münzfunde GL, pp. 19-22, 72-73, nos 16-17).
disposition: Historisches Museum, Bern; Historischer Verein des Kantons Glarus

summary: 348 antoniniani (radiates) - Elagabalus to Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: In 1900 69 coins bought by Wiener Hofmuseum, 13 by University of Vienna, and 1 by Robert Jörg

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 600 silver coins (denarii and radiates). The antoniniani (radiates) were described as being of 'large and medium module' according to Bocquillet. There were 38 different types from Commodus to Postumus Found during embankment works for the Château-l'Abbaye road.
220 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius for Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) - Philip I (AD 244-247).
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.
+2000 antoniniani (radiates) found in a bronze amphora: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Silver: 3 denarii, 208 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Diocletian/Galerius (Caesar) (AD 293); silver weight: 43.8-497.0g.
disposition: Landesmuseum Niederösterreich, St. Pölten (in 1977 in Wien), Austria

summary: The hoard comprised 21 sestertii and 2 dupondii or asses from Trajan to Severus Alexander. It was found on an ancient floor surface in the corner of a room during archaeological excavations.
270 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 70 antoniniani (radiates), 200 sestertii. 107 coins were examined: 16 antoniniani (radiates), 91 sestertii: Trajan - Marius (AD 269).

A hoard found in 1979 to the north west of Bath and thought to be complete except for six coins. Very little is known about the discovery of the hoard, except that it was associated with a few fragments of lead which may be derived from a container. 1'807 of the coins were cleaned and catalogued prior to the resale and dispersal of the hoard; 1805 antoniniani, 1 denarius and 1 quinarius, ranging from Gallienus to Allectus.

During ancient excavations on a Roman iron production site, a hoard of 110 official and local imitation radiates was found. The coins ranged from issues of Valerian I to Tetricus I and II, with a single outlier of Marcus Aurelius.
3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: Over 191 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: 1 Aurelian, 190 Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
10 antoniniani: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
70 coins found with a leather bag: 22 denarii, 47 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Radnevo, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 28-97

summary: The hoard comprised more than 1,000 (?) coins, which were either bronzes or radiates. 72 coins were preserved in Auzances. The bronzes were extremely worn and sometimes illegible. 62 were sestertii and 7 dupondii or asses, although TAF does not assign denomination by emperor.
The hoard was found in two vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
(150) 109 coins: 18 denarii, 19 antoniniani, 2 sestertii, 70 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 42.3-83.4 g.
disposition: History Museum, Kazanlak, Bulgaria (20 coins); Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1566-1672 (106 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 49 sestertii from Trajan to Philip I and 2 Provincial bronzes from Patras (Caracalla).
497 bronze coins: 496 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Venezia (252 coins)

summary: 1258 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 1623.4-3383.4 g.
4-5,000 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II found in a ceramic vessel (AD 271-274).
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).
57 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-254).
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest; Museum Dunaújváros, Hungary

summary: (3500-3600) 3106 antoniniani: Trebonianus Gallus - Tacitus (AD 276); silver weight: c.640.1-4436.6 g
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard comprised Roman coins dating to the third century AD.
127 silver coins: 86 denarii, 41 antoniniani: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 174.4-359 g.
12 antoniniani: 1 Philip, 11 Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 4.2-14 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pazardzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 969-980

summary: 12 silver coins: 4 denarii, 8 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 16-26.8 g.

The hoard comprised 353 radiates from Caracalla to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus with a terminus post quem of AD 257. The alloy of the two latest coins (RIC 241, 377) is described by FMRD as extremely good which is taken as an indication that these coinsmust date from the beginning of the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253), and not AD 257 as suggested in RIC. FMRD therefore gives the terminus post quem as 253 and sees a relationship between the deposition of the hoard and the incursions of the Germans the same year.
disposition: Stadtmuseum Ludwigshafen (but some coins are lost)

summary: Over 16,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Probus (AD 276-382). Found placed in two amphoras together with jewelry and silverware.
disposition: Musée de Bretagne, Rennes, France (4,159 coins)

summary: A hoard of 16 denarii (Vespasian - Caracalla), found in 1832, approx. 20 min from the so-called stone bridge between Rhede and Borken, on a field in Vardingholt. The coins were sold in 1843 at auction in Münster.

In 1816 an earthenware container was found with approximately 550 coins (mostly silver, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander), close to the SE corner of the Roman fort during the construction of the national road. Most of the coins were integrated in the collections of the Landgraf in Homburg. By the time they eventually reached the Saalburgmuseum, they had been mixed up with coins from the 1897 hoard.

A hoard of 11 coins (denarii and bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to Alexander Severus) was found in 1965 in a walled Roman stone cellar, west of the Jewish cemetery. It lay concealed without a container under the threshold to the cellar.
1 multiple of 3 aurei Carinus for Magnia Urbica; 1 silver medallion Valerian I and Gallienus for Valerian II (Caesar).
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
Around 200 denarii. 7 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235) are known..
The hoard comprised 658 silver coins (denarii, a few antoniniani and one drachm from Caesarea in Cappadocia) from Republican issues of Mark Antony to Severus Alexander.
disposition: Kantonsarchäologie Zürich, Fundmünzenbearbeitungsstelle, Münzkabinett der Stadt Winterthur

summary: The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 400 Roman sestertii from Nerva or Trajan to Postumus. 77 coins were examined.
1014 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: 165 coins (163 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Domitian to Alexander Severus), found with 2 silver bracelets ca. 3 km east of the Römerstraße. The coins were destroyed during the war.
disposition: Staatliche Münzsammlung München (lost during WWII; one bracelet survived)

summary: 500 sestertii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 226).

The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)
800 silver coins: 503 denarii, 297 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247). Near the hoard was discovered a votive inscription.
disposition: Muzeul Olteniei, Craiova, Romania; inv. no. I 3555

summary: The hoard comprised a large greyware 'olla' filled with small bronze coins, totalling approximately 2,000. These were partially dispersed although 500 coins were studied by Janicaud and 137 examples donated to the Musée de Guéret. No coins of the Gallic Empire were found in this hoard. The hoard was found when a farmer's plough struck a vessel.
300 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Postumus (AD 260-269) found in a ceramic vessel; silver weight: 82.0-764.7g.
The hoard comprised 84 tetradrachms dated between AD 211-217/8.

Hoard of gold and silver coins of circa 6 kilos: 3.85 silver, 2.26 gold. The gold coins were wrapped in leather and together with most of the silver ones they were distributed among the finders. 14 antoniniani (radiates) have been studied so far: Gordian III 8, and Philip I for Otacilia Severa 3, Gallienus 1, Claudius II 2.
Around 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) found with amphoras on a shipwreck. 229 coins were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293).
The hoard comprised 12 bronze coins, 5 of which have been identified.

462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
10 bronze coins minted in Deultum: Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Otacilia Severa.
Originally 460 coins - denarii and antoniniani (radiates), of which 459 were documented: Titus - Valerian I (AD 253-259).
21 denarii: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 233-235).
150 coins: 140 sestertii, 10 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus/Gallienus (AD 251-268). A silver patera and a lead weight were discovered together with these coins.

391 silver coins: 287 denarii from Vespasian to Gordian III; 101 antoniniani from Gordian III to Philip I; 3 bronze coins: 1 sestertius, 1 provincial, 1 unidentified (AD 244-249); silver weight: 437.2-913.2 g.
76 silver coins: 54 denarii, 22 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found during landscaping and construction work at the Tennis Club, Cherchell.
The hoard (8 denarii and antoniniani, Elagabalus - Philip I) was found at the bottom of a container during construction work at Heilbronn street.
Unknown initial number of coins. 18 antoniniani (radiates) are kept in a private collection: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard comprised a small earthenware vessel containing 100 'small bronzes' (radiates) of which 86 were identified by the finder: Valerian I and Gallienus/ Gallienus (sole) for Gallienus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274).
1,168 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) and denarii found while metal detecting. Probably, ending with coins of Philip I (AD 244-249).

37 provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis 22, Anchialus 7, Hadrianopolis 6, Nicopolis ad Istrum 1 and Serdica 1. Y. Youroukova published five coins of Gordian III and one of Tranquillina, minted in Hadrianopolis.

In 1898 42 coins (1 denarius and 41 antoniniani, Macrinus - Postumus) coins came into view during peat digging on the field 'Am Schachen' in the area of Spesbach. The coins were concealed together in a clump, 70-80 cm below the surface. The coins were lost during WWII.
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.
The hoard comprised 13 sestertii and dupondii from the first century AD to Gordian III, found in a large pithos. They might have been be part of a larger hoard.
52 silver coins were discovered in the modern suburbs of the city: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2320 /1-52

summary: 809 silver coins: 91 denarii, 718 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) - Valerian I (AD 258). Found with two ceramic vessels.

The hoard was found in a vessel and contained between 200 and 300 coins of Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip, Otacilla, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Hostilian, Trebonianus Gallus, Valerian, Valerian II, Mariniana and Salonina.

A hoard comprising 5 sestertii from Domitian to Macrinus. It has been interpreted as a purse or a small votive deposit. It was found on a hilltop above a cliff during metal detectorist's surveys (2002 and 2004).
Uncertain originally number of coins. 66 silver coins: 6 denarii, 60 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 84.9-171.3 g.

822 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295). Finding spots according to the Arad dealers from whom Milne bought the hoards in Cairo. The two hoards had almost the same composition, got mixed together on the way back to England, therefore have been listed as a single find.
Large number of silver coins. Only 14 pieces were identified: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Aurei found in a Germanic princess grave. Three of the coins, pierced, where part of a necklace: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius(2). One in the mouth: Gallienus. Rich funerary inventory.
disposition: Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens, Weimar, Germany (inv. nos. 16-19)

summary: 2,239 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 2,181 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 1 as, 47 cast sestertii: Republic - Valerian and Gallienus (AD 254-256); circa 50 kilos.
disposition: Gabinetto Numismatico di Milano, Italy (inv.nos. M.0.9.22769-M.0.9.25007)

summary: 72 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) (AD 203); silver weight: 133.5-256.7g
64 antoniniani (radiates) found near a kiln within the south-west district of the Roman city: Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).

The hoard comprised a bronze vessel containing approximately 6,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) (2,500 coins according to Guilmeth). 19 examples were acquired by the Musée de Rouen (Inv. I, no. 411) Found by a peasant called Renard; silver weight: c. 1621.0-7499.1g.
The hoard comprised 20 silver coins from Julia Domna, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus and Salonina.

The hoard was found inside a coarse-ware vessel, of a blackish colour. The coins were within a compacted, ferruginous mass and comprised 47 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 259.
An unknown quantity of coins was found in the outskirts of an ancient settlement. 31 silver coins were examined: 13 antoniniani, 18 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2579

summary: 9 bronze coins, date, grave: Gaius - Quintillus (AD 270).

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwritten note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.

The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: 17,533 antoniniani (59 kg) found in a bronze vessel: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus) (AD 249-251)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 932

summary: Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 37 denarii ranging up to Gordian III and was found with Iron Age coins seen as a separate group (Stonea Grange I group I). Part of the group was detected from site prior to excavation.
1,361 coins: 451 antoniniani (radiates), 909 denarii, 1 as: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258). Found with a limestone mortarium.
363 silver coins which were first placed in a bag and then in a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2205

summary: An unknown original number of coins. 232 antoniniani (radiates) and 56 denarii are known: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-269).
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: The hoard comprised 84 coins (probably radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II, Otacilia Severa, Trajan Decius, Herennius Etruscus, Hostilian, Herennia Etruscilla, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina and Valerian II.

The hoard comprise a pot of at least 2,721 coins, found while unrooting a tree. The hoard contained also a silver ring with a engraved gem setting. Coins range from Gordian III to Carinus. Of the 2,555 coins known to Vischer, 5 (Gordian III, Gallienus (2), Severina, Aurelian) are denarii, the others are radiates.
disposition: Archäologie Baselland; Historisches Museum Basel; Solothurn

summary: Originally a hoard of 68 coins but one went astray. From the 67 remaining coins (62 dupondii and 5 asses), 23 are completely illegible. The coins are heavily worn, suggested a much later burial than the latest coin.
1,156 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) together with 136 bronze coins found in two ceramic vessels ranging from Trajan to Gallienus.
The hoard comprised 35 bronze coins: 2 dupondii of Nero, 1 sestertius of Antoninus Pius and 32 bronzes of Postumus - 'all sizes'.

A hoard of 124 coins, comprising tetradrachms (Philip I - Gallus), denarii (Domitian - Alexander Severus, one quinarius (Caracalla) and one provincial bronze coin (Gordian III & Abgar), found at Dura in G1, during the season 1936–7. No container was reported.
18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: 28 antoniniani found during a fieldwalking: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256).
133 sestertii studied from a total of 300 found: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 2543-259).
91 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 18

summary: Three coins found on surface one next to the other (AD 260-274).
2,648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 1,094 antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Valerian I, Gallienus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Claudius II, Divus Claudius II, Quintillus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelian. Silver weight: 208.4-798.1 g.
Possible part of a larger hoard. Only 4 antoniniani (radiates) are known; silver weight: 5.0g.

820 denarii and antoninani: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260); 640 provincial bronzes. 500 provincial coins were minted in Tomis (144 types described in detail) for issuers from Septimius Severus to Philip I. Other types were mentioned only if they were new in 1893 publication from the catalogue by Mionnet
The hoard comprised 224 coins from Nerva to Aurelian. This included 28 sestertii from Nerva to Septimius Severus, 1 worn dupondius or as and 95 radiates from Gordian III to Victorinus and Aurelian.

In the summer of 1935, a third, smaller, hoard composed of 59 antoniniani from Gallienus to Probus was found in Edlington among the rocks known as the Crags. Some fragments of a native calcite-gritted jar, found near the coins, may have formed their container. One coin of Salonina and one of Tetricus II were found some time after the main hoard, but clearly belonged to it.
43 coins, part of a larger hoard: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
A hoard of uncertain size, of which only 7 coins are known from Postumus (Elmer 131, 314, 335, 565, 566, 593) to Victorinus (Elmer 683).
259 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 257)
disposition: National History Museum of Romania Bucharest 1971 (194 coins); ing. Octavian Lucian (65 coins) in 1971

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.
1310 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-259) coins; silver weight: 1496-3124.7 g.
79 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210). "Only 18 coins were found at first, the remainder being recovered when an excavation of the site was carried out the following month."
240 denarii (Commodus - Gordian III) were found during renovations of a house in 1933. The coins were to the Ingolstadt museum but lost in 1945.
6 aurei: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 255-256). The hoard comprises also gold and silver jewelry and tableware. Gold weight aurei: 32.8-41.1 g; silver weight: 645.2 g
disposition: Museum of the Romano-Gallic civilisation, Lyon; Museé des Beaux-Arts, Lyon

summary: Circa 400 coins of which 87 were studied: Gallienus (sole) - Tetrarchy(AD 299).

find_spot_name: ROME 1911 - BETWEEN VIA G. BRANCA, B. FRANKLIN AND THE TIBER
summary: 885 silver and bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
Unknown originally number of coins. 19 pieces are known - 7 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Filip I (AD 244-247).
The hoard comprised approx. 2,500 sestertii, ranging from the 1st to the 3rd century AD, finishing under Gallienus, and found in a burial in Akriai, near Gytheion.
In a bronze bucket 951 bronze coins: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-261).

A ceramic vessel with 1,032 Roman provincial bronze coins minted in Marcianopolis, Nicopolis ad Istrum, Callatis, Odessus, Anchialus, Augusta Traiana, Hadrianopolis, Philippopolis and Creteia-Flaviopolis: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 201 (894 coins)

summary: (619) 607 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 235 imperial denarii and 371 antoniniani: M. Antony to Trajan Decius (AD 249-250); silver weight: 775.8-2053.0 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 13

summary: 53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.
The hoard comprised two Roman Imperial coins of Severus Alexander, found in grave 6 of the east cemetery in Thessaloniki.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 12359/1-36 (36 coins)

summary: 17 bronze coins with the latest issues of Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).

A hoard of 7+ antoniniani (Caracalla - Valerian and Gallienus) was found in 1850 during the excavation of a foundation trench at the town exit. The coins were lying together in rolls. There find is incomplete, only 7 coins were described.
Over 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates), and a bronze clasp. Among these coins were identified issuers such as Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I.

A small hoard of 9 coins of Faustina II to Gallienus (sole reign), found at base of stone-lined pit at SE corner of ambulatory wall of later octagonal temple (building VI).Five of the coins could not be identified but were "not later than AD 270" (Wedlake 1982, 45). Denominations not given and the coins cannot be identified in the listing from the site. I have assumed them to be copper alloy. They are given as Faustina II (1), Gordian III (1), Gallienus (sole reign) (2) and unidentifed "up to AD 270" (5).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing numerous antoniniani (radiates) including issues of Gallienus, Claudius II and Tetricus I.

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.

750 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 726 pieces studied: 502 antoniniani, 224 denarii: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: c. 940.4-2135.9 g. Found together with bronze statuettes of horses.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2525; History Museum, Kardzhali, Bulgaria;

summary: The hoard comprised 225 sestertii from Trajan to Treboninanus Gallus (AD 251-253).

Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver weight: 2577.8-6108.2
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Nationale de France

summary: Unknown number of silver coins. 236 are in the Museum collection in Ruse: 230 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Republic - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria;inv. no. 1661

summary: The hoard was found between "Place de la Crémaillère" and "Rue de la Charité", on the Est of "Hôpital de la Charité", in a bronze pitcher. It comprised c. 1300 coins.
At the site of a newly constructed school building in 1957 three denarii (Septimius Severus - Caracalla) were found in the topmost burnt layer below a stone of a Roman wall.
Unknown number of antoniniani. Dr. Harlanov examined 15 pieces: Caracalla 1, Gordian III 13, Philip I 1; silver weight: 20.1-37.6 g.
Circa 20 sestertii of Gordian III (AD 238-244) found in a layer of ashes.
100 sestertii found together on an opus signinum floor: Hadrian - Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) (AD 251-253).
43 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 12.6-52.8 g.

A hoard of 94 denarii, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Severus Alexander, found at the Roman fort Vetoniana, inside the enclosure wall of the temple Jupiter Dolichenus. The hoard included objects as well.
The hoard comprised 53 bronze coins dated between AD 69 and AD 247-249.
(102) 101 silver coins: 24 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 131.2-264.8 g.
4,942 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Elagabalus (AD 222).
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania, 3,500 coins; County Museum, Pitești, Romania, 867 coins; Museum of History, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania, 531 coins; Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania, 44 coins

summary: A hoard of 52 bronze antoniniani (Gallienus - Tetricus) found in the quarry of Weisenau in 1910.

The hoard comprised 1,016 coins (1,015 antoniniani-radiates and 1 denarius). The hoard was discovered by two workmen on a building site, less than 50 metres from the Gallo-Roman baths, in an earthenware pot that got broken. The Hôtel de Ville d'Allonnes has preserved 386 coins from the hoard.
1,606 silver coins: 604 denarii, 1,002 antoniniani of the 1st-3rd centuries AD.
19 antoniniani found during archaeological excavations: Aurelian, Tacitus, Probus
The hoard comprised a ceramic container, the characteristics of which are unknown which contained 667 sestertii, one dupondius from Vespasian to Gordian III and one Provincial bronze of Hadrian.
disposition: Museo Arqueologico Provincial de Alicante, Spain

summary: 43 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 206-210). Found together jewels and dices embedded in a wall.
A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.

The hoard comprised about 50 kg antoniniani (radiates) of Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Divo Claudio, Quintillus, Aurelian and Tacitus. 2,226 coins and one blank have been studied.
(c. 2000) (133, 46) coins: Republic ?, Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); Silver weight: c.528.6-2441.5 g.
Hoard of over 5,000 antoniniani (radiates) and imitations: Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 8,864 antoniniani (radiates) Valerian I - Carinus (tpq AD 283, Numerian). Silver weight: 1596.1-6470.3 g.
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
55 silver coins, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, found during construction work.
108 bronze coins of Postumus: double sestertii, sestertii, imitations (AD 267-269).
1,745 coins: 1,742 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 285); silver weight: 318.0-439.9 g.
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 7.9-46.6 g.

14 bronze coins, ranging from Caracalla to Philip, found in a clay vessel in the destruction layer of a building in the north section of the Agora. More than 100 bronze (provincial, judging from those ill. in fig. 4 in AEMTh 18, 2004, p. 382) coins were also found in the same layer.

The hoard comprised more than 35,000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape Fteni Punta. The hoard was found on a shipwreck (Syrna I) and has been interpreted as carrying wages or money for military expenses. The hoard was first found by a sponge diver, rescue excavations followed in 2002.
Around 60-80 kilos of coins found in two vessels. 2,830 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.
7 coins found in a money-box: 1 denarius, 1 plated denarius, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Nerva - Philip I (Marcia Otacilia Severa) (AD 246-247).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.nos. M 29)

summary: The hoard comprised 9,000 antoniniani (radiates) (35kg) found in a terracotta vessel: Valerian I - Dioletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293). L. Dancoisne bought 1000 of the more interesting and better conserved coins, which may not be representative of the whole assemblage. Found whilst digging in garden; silver weight: 1621.1-11249.1 g+.
(303) 292 silver coins: 240 denarii, 52 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249); silver weight: 380.4-892.2 g.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.

In 1837 six silver coins and one copper coin were unearthed in an arable field between Dambach and Hammerschmiede, in the vicinity of the Dambach Roman fort. The six silver coins were denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Julia Mamaea. The copper coin was an antoninianus of Carinus, that was probably not part of the hoard and has not been listed here.
Circa 500 antoniniani. Only 11 pieces were described in the first publication.
(c. 300) 22 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 261); silver weight: c. 82.0-374.0 g.
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (7 coins); collection L. Renard-Grenson, Liège, Belgium (13 coins)

summary: 2,484 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a jar in an underground room during excavations of a house.
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 151 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 41.7-187.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 327, 2 coins)

summary: Unknown original number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia, Gallienus, Salonina. Uncertain whether this is part of the 1840 hoard also found in Echternach.

Over 4,500 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 293 -294) found in a room (same rooms as KOM AUSHIM A51, A100, A115, A118, A119), stored on the floor, during excavations of a house.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 1,000 3rd century antoniniani (radiates), including an example of Gordian I or II.

There were 914 antoniniani (radiates) in the hoard. The obverse details for each coin were not recorded and it is not possible to assign the coins to mints. Although Mira (1995-7, 137) gives the total number of coins as 914, only 905 are accounted for in the catalogue.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 751.3g and 1558.7g
(c. 1200) 122 denarii: Nero - Maximinus I Tharax (AD 235-236); silver weight: c. 1,681.7-3,754.3 g.
The hoard comprised 2,445 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani-radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I (AD 257) found in a lead container.
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
495 silver coins: 1 denarius, 488 antoniniani (radiates): Augustus, Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 135.3-612.6 g.

Hoard found in a cooking pot (not preserved) during construction work for the Nordostbahn railway track. It comprised an unknown number of antoniniani, of which 204 (possibly the greater part) are preserved in public collection, ranging from Trebonianus Gallus to Claudius II. - After the publication in 1992, at least another 6 coins from this hoard were recorded, in a private collection in Diessenhofen. The sherds of the pot are described in the 1893 publication. Four Gallienus coins were also subjected to chemical analysis at the same time, pp. 11-12: "Derselbe hat drei Stücke auf ihre Zusammensetzung quantitativ und qualitativ, das vierte nur qualitativ untersucht und folgendes gefunden: I. 6 Theile Zinn, 94 Theile Kupfer; II. 30 Th. Silber, 0,3 Th. Gold, 69,7 Th. Kupfer; III. 18 Th. Antimon, 82 Th. Kupfer; IV. Kupfer, Antimon und wenig Bismuth."
disposition: Thurgauisches Historisches Museum, Frauenfeld (158 coins); Museum Allerheiligen, Schaffhausen (40 coins); Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (6 coins); private (6 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 66 g to 270.3g.
572 silver coins: 2 denarii, 570 antoniniani: Macrinus - Valerian I (AD 253 -259); Silver weight: 1143.8-2361.7g
5 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-269)
20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,600 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263.
15 antoniniani found together: Gallienus - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
2,236 silver coins: 415 denarii, 1,821 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A large hoard of silver coins was discovered by Bulgarian soldiers. 6 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Gordian III 5, Trajan Decius 1.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2735

summary: Over 1,054 coins were found, most of them oxidized together. Only 120 have been recorded to the level of the coin. Some 12 coins may have been lost (loose from the bulk of the hoard). Silver: 1054 (1, 127) coins; Silver weight: 285.7-2505.4g.
50 bronze coins, probably, placed in a wooden box with bone hinges: 49 sestertii, 1 as: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised a deposit of between 300 and 400 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Julia Mamaea and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 10 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Claudius II to Probus (276-282) found in a grave.
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Kardzhali: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Kardzhali, Bulgaria

summary: Unknown number of provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel. 25 pieces are known: Septimius Severus - Caracalla (AD 211-217).
19 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian. Unpublished.
The hoard comprised 150 antoniniani (radiates), of which 129 survive from Philip I to Claudius II/Victorinus. This is one of four hoards from the site. Silver weight: 31.3-233.2g.

The hoard was found during the excavation of the Roman town of Baelo and comprised 13 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Claudius II with a tpq of AD 269-270. The coins were stacked one on top of the other next to a piece of limestone.
21 antoniniani: Valerian I - Gallienus (AD 2659-268). Found in a ceramic jug with one handle.
disposition: National Bank of Romania, Numismatic Collection, Bucharest

summary: 376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: Said to have been found at Satala. The hoard comprised 17 antoniniani (radiates) dated between the reigns of Valerian I and Carus.
The hoard comprised 3 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and II, placed in a pile in the foundations of the wall of a Gallo-Roman villa. It has been interpreted by TAF as a foundation deposit.
