'The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel filled with approximately 40 gold, silver and bronze coins with portraits of Trajan, Claudius II and Probus. The composition of this hoard is thought to be suspect.' The hoard was found in a small valley on the Guillet property.
Over 20 denarii. No further information.

Approximately 10,000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: Unknown number of gold coins and jewelry: Severus Alexander - Claudius II (AD 2680270)? Together were found silver and gold jewelry, one gold diadem and two gold ingots.
The hoard comprised 22 silver coins from the reign of Macrinus (AD 217-218).

3,000 to 5,000 silver coins, ranging from Augustus to Severus Alexander, found while digging gravel close to the Jever castle, on the city moat. 2,200 coins were melted down, the rest dispersed. Zedelius published 564 coins attributed to the hoard.
disposition: Oldenburgisches Landesmuseum (part); Schloßmuseum Jever (part); Ostfriesisches Landesmuseum, Emden (part); Münster museum (part)

summary: Uknown number of denarii and antoniniani found in a ceramic vessel. 9 denarii are kept in the museum collection in Popovo: Marcus Aurelius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
6.7 kg of antoniniani, of which 2,125 pieces entered the museums in Sofia and Vidin: Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1079 (1990 coins); National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 8130-8264; 8679-8696 (153 coins)

summary: An unknown number of silver coins: 1 denarius, 16 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2631

summary: The hoard comprised an urn containing 218 (or 318) Roman silver coins, both denarii and antoniniani (radiates). A silver statue depicting a 'wise old man' was also discovered at the same findspot a little later. The hoard was found by a farmer called Filliol while working in his field; silver weight: c.60.4-563.7g.
190 coins found with a pot: Gordian III - Carinus (AD 283-285).
The hoard comprised about 4,000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be two hoards.
1,267 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Trajan to Philip I (AD 247-248) found with two ceramic vessels.

A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 253-270.
11 bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 241-244).
Grave goods: aurei of Elagabalus, 2 denarii Augustus, 2 drachms Gotarzes.

111 coins confiscated in 1981. The find encompassed 69 provincial coins from Thessalonica (Commodus - Philip II), 14 from Pella (Caracalla - Otacilia Severa), 6 from Edessa (Caracalla - Gordian III), 3 from Dion (Elagabalus - Maximinus); 1 from Stobi (Septimius Severus), 9 from the Koinon of Macedonia, 5 uncertain ones of 'Greek cities', 4 imperial coins (Vespasian - Maximinus).

Found during construction work, partially supervised by an archaeologist, in the ruins of a Roman rural building; 15 sestertii, Antoninus Pius to Philipp I, found together with shards possibly of a container. The hoard has been interpreted as a 'Bauopfer' or foundation deposit.
Twenty copper Roman coins from a salt spring: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
290 denarii ranging from Marc Antony to Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
189 antoniniani (radiates) found together in the theater of Caesaraugusta: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Work in progress.
160 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
disposition: AM Zagreb (41); ZM Sarajevo (114); Fojnica monastery; dispersed

summary: The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 24 sestertii, asses and antoniniani (radiates) from Augustus to Probus and was found in the courtyard garden of a house during excavations of the Roman town of Clunia.
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,049 bronze coins found in three ceramic vessels placed one next to the other: 1,045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: 1,337 denarii found in an amphora: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 228); silver weight: 1873.5-4183.1 g

The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.
(c. 200) 40 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver weight: 46.4-91.3 g.
During the digging of a ditch three asses were found placed in a small amphora which was placed in a bigger one: Sextus Pompeius as, Augustus as, Philip I as,

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO A)
summary: Hoard in grave, 114 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
157 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 43.5-370.6 g.
disposition: Collection Huybrigts, Tongeren, Belgium, in 1902; destroyed by fire in 1914

summary: 51H includes the coins which were found in front of the temple, in the court by an urn.
In 1835, a hoard of 12,000 coins was found there. Hundreds of antoniniani (radiates) of the Gallic emperors were discovered in 1852.
(104) 98 provincial bronze coins up to Gordian III (AD 238-244).
253 bronze coins: 252 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Vespasian - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).

A pit dug through remains of building 2/3 at Alchester Road, contained small hoard of 3 coins of Claudius Gothicus (268-70) found "cemented together in a stack". The pit fill was black, very ashy with burnt & smithing material mixed with unburnt stone. This demonstrates with other examples in area pattern of coin discard comparable to smaller urban foci elsewhere, though there are interesting anomalies within the Towcester group that would reward further study.Brown, A.E. & Woodfield, C. 1983. Excavations at Towcester, Northamptonshire: the Alchester Road Suburb. Northamptonshire Archaeology 18, 43-140
Within an ancient settlement was found a deposit of iron tools. Beneath were discovered 280 silver and bronze coins. The latest one from the mid-3rd century AD. No further information.

Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 4 coins provided some data: 2 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Marcus Aurelius, Elagabalus, Maximinus I Thrax, Gallienus (sole reign).
The hoard comprised 1 denarius of Elagabalus and 15 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 7.3 to 19.6 g.
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 20.8-37 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2247

summary: Uknown number of silver Roman coins. 1 denarius of Severus Alexander and 2 coins of Gordian III are known.
67 silver coins: 63 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Direction des antiquités historiques, Paris, France

summary: 27 silver denarii, from Vespasian to Severus Alexander (75-235 AD), have been found scattered over a cultivated field by volunteer archaeologists. Coins are now kept in the Archaeological Museum of Povegliano Veronese.
2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
135 sestertii found in a cooking pot covered by a plate: Domitian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236-238).
Unknown number of silver coins. 33 antoniniani seen by T. Gerasimov: Gordian III - Trajan Decius.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel filled with 15 Roman silver coins and 600 small bronzes of the same module (radiates). The reverse of one coin is given as MARTI PACIFERO, A/-. It appears to be an issue of Gallienus (RIC V/1 236?)
Unknown initial number of coins. 12 antoniniani are kept in the local museum of Sevlievo: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
186 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Severus Alexander, found compacted together during building work on the Augustusplatz. A few coins were lost.
12 silver coins: 1 denarius, 11 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
A hoard of an unknown number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Only 5 coins are documented: Domitian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Commodus, Philip I (AD ).
16 bronze coins were bought by the museum: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. XXV

summary: The hoard was hidden amongst a pile of Roman tiles and comprised more than 2,000 sestertii. TAF suggests that the large bronze of Gallienus should in fact be identified as a medallion.
(5 or 6 kg. coins, c.1500 coins?) silver coins, 16 recovered: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 21.5-34.9 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2499; 16 coins

summary: The hoard was found near Keldenich, on the Tanzberg in an earthenware urn that was shattered by the workers who found it. It comprised 10 pound (or 20?) of Roman silver coins. The coins (4000 according to Haupt) were dispersed and only the names of some of the emperors represented were recorded (Vespasian - Severus Alexander).
11 antoniniani (Gallienus - Divus Claudius, AD 270) found on the southwestern slope of the Sommerberg directly above Furtwangen.

Circa 500 silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver gilded bracelets and 3 silver rings. 50 antoniniani are kept in the History Museum in Lom: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Lom Bulgaria; (50 coins, 1 bracelet, 3 rings)

summary: 52 silver coins: 51 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) found with a ceramic jug: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); silver weight: 75.9-163.6g.
(3000) 2,873 denarii and antoniniani: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249)
disposition: Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum, Budapest, Hungary (6 coins), in 1865

summary: 20 Alexandrian bronzes found in ceramic vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Cleopatra VII - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
Group record for a hoard of six silver coins.
The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.

A hoard was found in Chassenon at some time in the nineteenth century AD and comprised 10 coins from Maximinus I Thrax to Aemilian. Some of the coins were kept by the family and can be identified by M. Dhénin. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 12.6-22.9 g.
1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.

The hoard was found in 1973 during archaeological program. The archaeologists discovered 45 kg of sestertii, in 12 rolls in a wood box. It comprised c. 1980 sestertii from Philip I - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Gallienus) (AD 253-268).
523 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 292-293) found in a jar, hidden in a hole dug out beneath the floor of underground room H, during excavations of a house.
disposition: 507 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard comprised a large number of denarii and radiates, although only 160 were recorded and were issues from Septimius Severus to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 50.3g to 413.7g.
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: 501 silver coins. 496 entered the museum collection in Pazardhzik: 78, 427: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 644.3-1323.4 g.
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1904-2087

summary: Hoard of circa 350 coins. 285 were seen: 284 antoniniani (radiates), 1 aureus: Claudius II - Diocletian (AD 284-294); gold weight: 5.34g; Silver: 284 coins; silver weight: 51.2-90.8 g.
Circa 500 coins, among which: 468 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Titus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
Eighteen aurei were found in a local earthenware pot. Some of them were pierced.
190 antoniniani, probably, part of Sushina 2: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Unknown initial number of silver coins. antoniniani recovered: 1 Gordian III, 3 Tranquilina (AD 238-241).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing between 2,000 and 3,000 coins. The hoard was immediately dispersed but contained at least 20 radiates of Gallienus and Postumus.
Republican to AD 193-221 Silver: 527 coins; Silver weight: 966.2-1890.2g
48 antoniniani: Gordian III - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 16

summary: Six denarii "fairly close together, possibly a small purse hoard. Not possible to obtain details of 2 of these, but the remaining 4 consists of: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
43 kg = +8,000 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 258)

The hoard comprised 100 coins 'une centaine'. Gricourt only saw three coins from the find. They were antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip and Herennia Etruscilla. A pharmacist from Somain discovered the hoard which was immediately dispersed.
About 100 antoniniani up to the 3rd century AD.
4,128 coins found in two vessels: 3 denarii, 4,125 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 252).

The hoard comprised 14 Roman Provincial coins, found in grave 11 in Methone: Dion (1 Elagabalus), Edessa (1 Caracalla, 1 Julia Domna), Thessalonica (1 Geta, 1 Commodus, 2 Elagabalus, 1 Julia Maesa, 1 Philip I), Pella (1 Julia Mamaia, 4 Gordian III).
It comprised 93 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 88 are now recorded: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,587 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
(1430) 976 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Found together with silverware and jewelry.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (976 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,400 denarii with the latest coin being of Severus Alexander (or according to Blanchet, Gordian III).

Two different accounts exist regarding the composition of this hoard both given by M. Guéroult. In Version A, all coins were found in the bottom of the pit at a depth of 19 metres, spread over an area measuring 1 metre by 5 metres. 31 examples were identified. In Version B, the hoard was found in a greyware vessel, buried at a depth of 10m and containing approximately 200 bronzes, of which 15 were identified. It is possible that these two accounts represent two lots from the same hoard and therefore the coins have been summarised together, with a note made of whether they are mentioned in Account A or Account B. The hoard was found by workers extracting stone from a large pit measuring 160 metres in circumference.
27 denarii: Vespasian for Titus (Caesar) - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: scattered in post pole - interpreted as save hoard, not ritual construction votive

summary: 1,937 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Musées Royaux d'Art et d'Histoire - Koninklijk Musea voor Kunst en Geschiedenis (Brussels)

summary: Circa 780 broze coins, 778 studied: 776 imperial bronzes, 1 dupondius/as, 1 provincial coin (koinon of Cyprus): Vespasian to Philip I.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale, Paris, France

summary: The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 249.6-505.0 g.
Around 25 kg = 7,656 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
The hoard comprised 39 radiates of Gallienus and Salonina, found in the Euripides / Peristeria cave, on the south of the island of Salamis.
Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), only 7 were recovered, period of AD 260-275; silver weight: c. 28.0-124.0 g.
1,200 imperial bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (Salonina) (AD 253-268).
Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel. 103 coins entered museum collection in Stara Zagora: 5 denarii, 96 antoniniani, 2 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4318-4327

summary: The hoard was found in two vessels and comprised 6,700 Provincial bronzes chiefly of Samos, ending with coins of Gallienus (sole reign). Other mints represented include Naxos, Ephesus, Magnesia ad Maeander and Smyrna. The two vessels were resting against the wall of a house, built west of the 'Cicero-Exedra'.
disposition: Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Münzkabinett; Samos, archaeological museum

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 1200 antoniniani (radiates). The following emperors were represented: Valerian, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus and Claudius II. It also included a radiate of Macrianus (SOLI INVICTO) and three of Postumus (CONCORD EQVIT; MONETA AVG; and P M TR P COS II P P). The last coin is a DIVO CLAVDIO radiate with eagle reverse.
98 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria found with a ceramic vessel: Probus - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 291-292). Briefly examined by Martin Price.
Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Elagabalus, 1 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), Pella (2 Gordian III, 1 Otacilia Severa), found in a grave.
